Currently, the longest period over which the Company is hedging exposure to variability in future cash flows is 20 years, specifically related to forecasted debt interest payments For fair value hedges, in 2010, the Company designated three interest rate swaps as fair value hedges to convert senior notes due in 2015, 2019, and 2020 from fixed-rate debt to floating-rate debt The interest rate swaps related to the senior notes due in 2015 matured in the fourth quarter of 2015; As for cash flow hedges, the Company has designated and accounts for interest rate swaps to hedge interest rate exposure on debt, interest rate lock agreements for debt issuances, and swaptions to mitigate the risk of increasing interest rates on forecasted fixed premium product sales For the years ending December 31, 2015, 2014, and 2013, amounts recognized in earnings related to cash flow hedges due to ineffectiveness were $1 million The estimated net amount of existing pretax losses as of December 31, 2015, that the Company anticipates reclassifying to earnings within the next twelve months is $4 million, which includes $2 million of pretax gains to be recorded as a reduction to interest and debt expense and $6 million of pretax losses to be recorded in net investment income; //In Part I, Item 1, Entergy Corporation, under the category of Utility operating companies and System Energy, discusses the continued effectiveness of the Clean Energy Standards/Zero Emissions Credit program (CES/ZEC), the establishment of certain long-term agreements on acceptable terms with the Energy Research and Development Authority of the State of New York in connection with the CES/ZEC program, and the NYPSC approval of the transaction on acceptable terms Entergy refueled the FitzPatrick plant in January and February 2017 In October 2015, Entergy determined that it would close the Pilgrim plant; In December 2016, Entergy announced an agreement with Consumers Energy to terminate the existing PPA for the Palisades plant in 2018, intending to shut it down permanently on May 31, 2022, after refueling in the spring of 2017 In October 2015, Entergy decided to close the FitzPatrick plant at the end of the fuel cycle in January 2017, but in August 2016, it entered into an agreement to sell the FitzPatrick plant to Exelon, with the sale closing in March 2017 Entergy Wholesale Commodities also includes the ownership of two non-operating nuclear facilities, Big Rock Point in Michigan and Indian Point 1 in New York, which were acquired when Entergy purchased the Palisades and Indian Point 2 nuclear plants, respectively, and these facilities are in various stages of the decommissioning process; The base sales price, excluding adjustments, was approximately $490 million Entergy Wholesale Commodities had purchased RISEC for $346 million in December 2011 In December 2016, Entergy announced that it reached an agreement with Consumers Energy to terminate the Power Purchase Agreement (PPA) for the Palisades plant on May 31, 2018; This decision came after management’s extensive analysis of the economics and operating life of the plant following the NRC’s decision in September 2015 to place the plant in its “multiple/repetitive degraded cornerstone column” (Column 4) of its Reactor Oversight Process Action Matrix The Pilgrim plant is expected to cease operations on May 31, 2019, after refueling in the spring of 2017 and operating through the end of that fuel cycle In December 2015, Entergy Wholesale Commodities closed on the sale of its 583 MW Rhode Island State Energy Center (RISEC), located in Johnston, Rhode Island; In October 2015, Entergy determined that it would close the Pilgrim plant no later than June 1, 2019 In January 2017, Entergy announced a settlement with New York State to shut down Indian Point 2 by April 30, 2020, and Indian Point 3 by April 30, 2021, resolving all legal challenges to Indian Point’s operating license renewal On December 29, 2014, the Vermont Yankee plant ceased power production, and in November 2016, Entergy agreed to sell 100% of the membership interest in Entergy Nuclear Vermont Yankee to NorthStar

//In the context of our assessment of impairment, we recorded a gross other-than-temporary impairment of $1 15 billion for the year 2009, which is a significant increase compared to the $122 million recorded for the year 2008 Of the total impairment recorded, $227 million was related to credit and was recognized in our consolidated statement of income; Finally, the balance at the end of the period was $140 million in 2018, down from $319 million in 2017 This data reflects the company's assessment of its fixed maturity securities and the associated credit loss impairments; During 2018, new credit loss impairments amounted to $1 million, compared to $10 million in 2017 Additionally, there were no additional credit loss impairments on securities that had previously been impaired in 2018, while there were $11 million in 2017 The increases due to the passage of time on previously recorded credit losses were $10 million in 2018 and $15 million in 2017; Reductions for securities that matured, paid down, prepaid, or were sold during the period were significant, with a reduction of $162 million in 2018 and $58 million in 2017 Furthermore, reductions for securities impaired to fair value during the period were $24 million in 2018 and $13 million in 2017 The accretion of credit loss impairments previously recognized due to an increase in cash flows expected to be collected was a reduction of $4 million in 2018 and $5 million in 2017; The remaining $928 million was attributed to factors other than credit, which is discussed in more detail below, and was recognized, net of related taxes, in Other Comprehensive Income (OCI) in our consolidated statement of condition The $227 million related to credit was composed of $151 million associated with expected credit losses, $54 million related to management's decision to sell the impaired securities prior to their recovery in value, and $22 million related to adverse changes in the timing of expected future cash flows from the securities The majority of the impairment losses were related to non-agency securities that were collateralized by mortgages, for which management concluded that credit losses had occurred based on the present value of the securities' expected future cash flows

however, domestic cup and lid sales volumes were 5% lower than in 2004 as a result of a rationalization of our customer base early in 2005; Operating profits in Shorewood for 2005 were 17% above 2004 levels and about equal to 2003 levels Improved margins in Shorewood resulting from a rationalization of the customer mix and the effects of improved manufacturing operations, including the successful start-up of our South Korean tobacco operations, more than offset cost increases for board and paper and the impact of unfavorable foreign exchange rates in Canada Beverage Packaging net sales in 2005 were $597 million, which were $595 million in 2004 and $589 million in 2003; //In 2006, Industrial Packaging earnings are expected to improve significantly in the first quarter compared with the fourth quarter of 2005 Average price realizations for Industrial Packaging should continue to benefit from price increases announced in late 2005 and early 2006 for linerboard and domestic boxes Containerboard sales volumes in Industrial Packaging are expected to drop slightly in the first quarter of 2006 due to fewer shipping days, but growth is anticipated for U; Operating profits in Consumer Packaging for 2005 declined 22% from 2004 and 31% from 2003, as improved price realizations of $46 million and favorable operations in the mills and converting operations of $60 million could not overcome the impact of cost increases in energy, wood, polyethylene, and other raw materials totaling $120 million, lack-of-order downtime of $13 million, and other costs of $8 million In millions, Consumer Packaging sales in 2005 were $2,590, in 2004 were $2,605, and in 2003 were $2,465 In millions, Consumer Packaging operating profit in 2005 was $126, in 2004 was $161, and in 2003 was $183; In the category of Industrial Packaging, demand for Industrial Packaging products is closely correlated with non-durable industrial goods production in the United States, as well as with demand for processed foods, poultry, meat, and agricultural products In addition to prices and volumes, major factors affecting the profitability of Industrial Packaging include raw material and energy costs, manufacturing efficiency, and product mix Industrial Packaging's net sales for the year 2005 increased by 2% compared with 2004, and were 18% higher than in 2003, reflecting the inclusion of International Paper Distribution Limited (formerly International Paper Pacific Millennium Limited) beginning in August 2005

#//In the context of our assessment of impairment, we recorded a gross other-than-temporary impairment of $1 15 billion for the year 2009, which is a significant increase compared to the $122 million recorded for the year 2008 Of the total impairment recorded, $227 million was related to credit and was recognized in our consolidated statement of income; The remaining $928 million was attributed to factors other than credit, which is discussed in more detail below, and was recognized, net of related taxes, in Other Comprehensive Income (OCI) in our consolidated statement of condition The $227 million related to credit was composed of $151 million associated with expected credit losses, $54 million related to management's decision to sell the impaired securities prior to their recovery in value, and $22 million related to adverse changes in the timing of expected future cash flows from the securities The majority of the impairment losses were related to non-agency securities that were collateralized by mortgages, for which management concluded that credit losses had occurred based on the present value of the securities' expected future cash flows; Treasury securities and obligations of U S government authorities and agencies had an amortized cost of $10,930 million, gross unrealized gains of $663 million, gross unrealized losses of $295 million, a fair value of $11,298 million, and no other-than-temporary impairments in AOCI; These securities are classified as asset-backed securities in the investment securities tables mentioned earlier As described in note 1, management periodically reviews the fair values of investment securities to determine if other-than-temporary impairment has occurred This review encompasses all investment securities and includes quantitative factors such as current and expected future interest rates, the length of time that a security's cost basis has exceeded its fair value, and investment securities for which we have issuer-specific concerns, regardless of quantitative factors; Obligations of U S states and their political subdivisions had an amortized cost of $2,254 million, with gross unrealized gains of $43 million, gross unrealized losses of $66 million, a fair value of $2,231 million, and no other-than-temporary impairments in AOCI; Gains and losses related to investment securities were reported for the years ended December 31

Revenue by quarter for the years ended December 31, 2017, 2016, and 2015 are as follows:; 3 million, and $45 2 million for the years ended December 31, 2017, 2016, and 2015, respectively We concentrate on developing technology innovations that will deliver growth through the introduction of new products and solutions, and also on driving continuous improvements in product cost, quality, safety, and sustainability; In the Seasonality section, our business experiences seasonality that varies by product line Because more construction and do-it-yourself projects occur during the second and third calendar quarters of each year in the Northern Hemisphere, our security product sales, typically, are higher in those quarters than in the first and fourth calendar quarters However, our Interflex business typically experiences higher sales in the fourth calendar quarter due to project timing; We manage our R&D team as a global group with an emphasis on a global collaborative approach to identify and develop new technologies and worldwide product platforms We are organized on a regional basis to leverage expertise in local standards and configurations In addition to regional engineering centers in each geographic region, we also operate a global engineering center of excellence in Bangalore, India

#In 2012, the net revenue for Entergy Wholesale Commodities decreased to $1,854 million Overall, the net revenue decreased by $191 million, or 9%, in 2012 compared to 2011, primarily due to lower pricing in contracts to sell power and a decrease in nuclear fleet volume caused by more unplanned and refueling outage days in 2012 compared to 2011 This decrease was partially offset by the exercise of resupply options in purchase power agreements, allowing Entergy Wholesale Commodities to supply power from alternative sources when the plant was not operational; //In 2011, the net revenue for Entergy Wholesale Commodities was $2,045 million The changes in the realized price for nuclear contributed a decrease of $194 million Additionally, the nuclear volume saw a reduction of 33 million, while other factors contributed positively with an increase of 36 million; //In the analysis of the change in net revenue for Entergy Corporation and Subsidiaries, the 2012 net revenue was $4,969 million The retail electric price for 2012 was $236 million The Louisiana Act 55 financing savings obligation amounted to $165 million; Consequently, the 2013 net revenue increased to $5,524 million The variance in the retail electric price is primarily attributed to a formula rate plan increase at Entergy Louisiana, which became effective in January 2013 This increase includes adjustments related to the Waterford 3 steam generator replacement project, which was placed in service in December 2012; It is important to note that energy efficiency revenues are offset by costs included in other operation and maintenance expenses and do not affect net income Moreover, there was an annual base rate increase at Entergy Texas, which became effective in July 2012, following the PUCT’s order issued in September 2012 in the November 2011 rate case Lastly, a formula rate plan increase at Entergy Mississippi became effective in September 2013; Furthermore, there was an increase in the capacity acquisition rider at Entergy Arkansas, which was approved by the APSC and became effective with the first billing cycle of December 2012, relating to the Hot Spring plant acquisition The net income effect of the Hot Spring plant cost recovery is also limited to a portion representing an allowed return on equity on the net plant investment, with the remainder offset by the Hot Spring plant costs in other operation and maintenance expenses, depreciation expenses, and taxes other than income taxes In addition, there were increases in the energy efficiency rider, as approved by the APSC, effective in July 2013 and July 2012

#8 billion in 2014, $2 6 billion in 2013, and $2 6 billion in 2012; //In the category of Operating Revenues, the Freight revenues for the year 2013 amounted to $20,684 million, which represents a 5% increase compared to the $19,686 million recorded in 2012, and a 6% increase from the $18,508 million in 2011 The Other revenues for 2013 totaled $1,279 million, reflecting a 3% increase from $1,240 million in 2012, and an 18% increase from $1,049 million in 2011 The Total revenues for 2013 reached $21,963 million, which is a 5% increase from the $20,926 million in 2012, and a 7% increase from the $19,557 million in 2011; Our fuel surcharge programs generated freight revenues of $2 6 billion in 2013, $2 6 billion in 2012, and $2; In 2014, the fuel surcharge increased by 6%, driven by a 7% increase in carloadings In 2013, the fuel surcharge was essentially flat compared to 2012, as lower fuel prices offset improved fuel recovery provisions and the lag effect of our programs, which typically trail fluctuations in fuel prices by approximately two months In 2014, other revenue increased from 2013 due to higher revenues at our subsidiaries, primarily those that broker intermodal and automotive services, as well as accessorial revenue driven by increased volume and per diem revenue for container usage, which was previously included in automotive freight revenue; We generate freight revenues by transporting freight or other materials from our six commodity groups, and these revenues vary with volume (carloads) and Average Revenue per Carload (ARC) Changes in price, traffic mix, and fuel surcharges drive the ARC, and we provide some customers with contractual incentives for meeting or exceeding specified cumulative volumes or shipping to and from specific locations, which we record as reductions to freight revenues based on actual or projected future shipments Freight revenues are recognized as shipments move from origin to destination, and we allocate these revenues between reporting periods based on the relative transit time in each reporting period, recognizing expenses as they are incurred; Other revenues include earnings from our subsidiaries, revenues from commuter rail operations, and accessorial revenues, which are earned when customers retain equipment owned or controlled by us or when we perform additional services such as switching or storage We recognize other revenues as we perform services or meet contractual obligations In 2013, freight revenues from five of our six commodity groups increased compared to 2012, although revenue from agricultural products saw a slight decline

We remain liable to the extent that our reinsurers do not meet their obligation under the reinsurance contracts, and as such, we regularly evaluate the financial condition of our reinsurers and monitor concentration of our credit risk The estimation of the allowance for doubtful accounts requires judgment for which key inputs typically include historical trends regarding uncollectible balances, disputes and credit events as well as specific reviews of balances in dispute or subject to credit impairment The allowance for doubtful accounts on reinsurance assets was $140 million and $187 million at December 31, 2018 and 2017, respectively; For the years ended 2016, the free cash flow (non-GAAP) was $402,489 thousand, which increased from $320,738 thousand in 2015, and decreased from $392,643 thousand in 2014 The increase in free cash flow of $82 million in 2016, compared to 2015, is attributed to an increase in cash flows from operations, which was partially offset by higher levels of capital spending to support growth initiatives and facilities requirements, as well as capitalized spending for ongoing software development initiatives The decrease in free cash flow of $72 million in 2015, compared to 2014, was due to higher levels of capital spending for growth initiatives and facilities requirements, along with capitalized spending for ongoing software development initiatives, although this was partially offset by an increase in cash flows from operations; The Less: proportional adjustment factor on operating cash activities for 2015 was -$558 million, which represented a decrease of $199 million from 2014's -$359 million and an increase of $475 million from 2013's -$834 million The Proportional Adjusted Operating Cash Flow for 2015 was $1,741 million, showing an increase of $309 million from 2014's $1,432 million, but a decrease of $449 million from 2013's $1,881 million The Less: proportional maintenance capital expenditures, net of reinsurance proceeds for 2015 was -$449 million, which was an increase of $36 million from 2014's -$485 million and a decrease of $50 million from 2013's -$535 million; The proportional adjustment factor, proportional maintenance capital expenditures, and proportional non-recoverable environmental capital expenditures are calculated based on the percentage owned by noncontrolling interests for each entity and their corresponding consolidated cash flow metrics; Free cash flow may differ from similar non-GAAP financial measures used by other companies and may not be comparable to similarly titled captions of other companies due to potential inconsistencies in calculation methods Free cash flow is deemed important for enabling investors to better understand and evaluate ongoing operating results, providing greater transparency in reviewing and understanding overall financial, operational, and economic performance, as it accounts for certain capital expenditures necessary for business operations

#The average position for 2012 had a fair value of $546 million and a market risk of $55 million, while in 2011, the average position had a fair value of $1,644 million and a market risk of $164 million The decline in fair value of the average position for 2012 compared to 2011 was principally the result of the decline in average quantities underlying the weekly commodity position; The Companies often make specific assumptions that market participants would consider when pricing the asset or liability, including assumptions regarding risk and the inherent risks associated with the inputs to valuation techniques The Companies employ valuation techniques that aim to maximize the use of observable inputs while minimizing the reliance on unobservable inputs The accounting rules for fair value measurements and disclosures have established a fair value hierarchy, which prioritizes the inputs to valuation techniques used to measure fair value across three broad levels; The rules mandate that assets and liabilities be classified in their entirety based on the level of input that is utilized; //In the context of Fair Value Measurements, the accounting rules define fair value as the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date in a principal or most advantageous market Fair value is characterized as a market-based measurement that is determined based on inputs, which broadly refer to the assumptions that market participants utilize in pricing assets or liabilities These inputs can be categorized as readily observable, market corroborated, or generally unobservable firm inputs; //In 2012, the highest position in fair value was $1,477 million, while the market risk associated with this position was $148 million In contrast, in 2011, the highest position in fair value was $2,388 million, with a market risk of $239 million The lowest position in 2012 had a fair value of -$383 million and a market risk of -$38 million, whereas in 2011, the lowest position had a fair value of $368 million and a market risk of $37 million

//The table provides supplementary information on oil and gas producing activities, specifically focusing on the estimated quantities of proved oil and gas reserves In the United States, the proved developed and undeveloped reserves at the beginning of the year 2001 were 1,914 billion cubic feet In Europe, the reserves were 614 billion cubic feet, while in West Africa, there were no reserves reported; Future cash inflows are computed by applying year-end prices of oil and gas to the year-end quantities of those reserves The assumptions used to compute the proved reserve valuation do not necessarily reflect Marathon’s expectations of actual revenues to be derived from those reserves The reserve valuation assumes that all reserves will be disposed of by production, but if reserves are sold in place or subjected to participation by foreign governments, additional economic considerations could affect the amount of cash realized; The Standardized Measure of Discounted Future Net Cash Flows relating to Proved Oil and Gas Reserves indicates that future net cash flows are calculated by applying prescribed oil and gas selling prices used in determining year-end reserve estimates, adjusted for price changes provided by contractual arrangements, to estimated future production of proved oil and gas reserves, less estimated future development and production costs based on year-end costs and existing economic assumptions Future income tax expenses are computed by applying the appropriate year-end statutory tax rates to the pre-tax net cash flows relating to the Corporation’s proved oil and gas reserves Future net cash flows are discounted at the prescribed rate of 10%; By the end of 2003, the proved developed reserves in the United States were 1,067 billion cubic feet, in Europe were 421 billion cubic feet, and in West Africa were 528 billion cubic feet, leading to a consolidated total of 2,016 billion cubic feet, with no contributions from equity investees, resulting in continuing operations of 2,016 billion cubic feet and no discontinued operations The standardized measure of discounted future net cash flows and changes therein relating to proved oil and gas reserves was determined in accordance with Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No 69

#Since 2007, we have utilized foreign currency forward contracts to mitigate the risk from exchange rate fluctuations on inter-company transactions and projected inventory purchases for our Canadian subsidiary Beginning in December 2008, we also started using foreign currency forward contracts to reduce the risk associated with foreign currency exchange rate fluctuations on inter-company transactions for our European subsidiary It is important to note that we do not enter into derivative financial instruments for speculative or trading purposes; As of December 31, 2009, based on the foreign currency forward contracts outstanding, we receive US Dollars in exchange for Canadian Dollars at a weighted average contractual forward foreign currency exchange rate of 1 04 CAD per $1 00 and US Dollars in exchange for Euros at a weighted average contractual forward foreign currency exchange rate of 0; These amounts are included in prepaid expenses and other current assets on the consolidated balance sheet For further details, refer to Note 9 for a discussion of the fair value measurements Other income (expense), net included the following amounts related to changes in foreign currency exchange rates and derivative foreign currency forward contracts; #In 2017, the Total risk-based capital ratio must be at least 9 25% In 2018, the Total risk-based capital ratio must be at least 9; In 2016, the Tier 1 risk-based capital ratio must be at least 6 625% In 2017, the Tier 1 risk-based capital ratio must be at least 7; In 2019, the Tier 1 risk-based capital ratio must be at least 8 5% In 2015, the Total risk-based capital ratio must be at least 8; Based on the final Basel III rule, banking organizations with more than $15 billion in total consolidated assets are required to phase out any non-qualifying capital instruments issued before September 12, 2010 We began the additional tier 1 capital phase-out of our trust preferred securities in 2015, but we will be able to include these instruments in tier 2 capital as a non-advanced approaches institution Under Basel III, Common equity tier 1 capital predominantly includes common stockholders’ equity, less certain deductions for goodwill and other intangible assets net of related taxes, over-funded net pension fund assets, and deferred tax assets that arise from tax loss and credit carryforwards; banking regulators or as our understanding and interpretation of rules evolve, as mentioned in the Management’s Discussion and Analysis The reconciliation of regulatory ratios and ratio components using the Basel III Standardized Transitional rules and Basel III Standardized estimates on a fully-phased in basis for common equity tier 1 capital, total capital, and risk-weighted assets is provided in the table Common equity tier 1 capital totaled $13,822 million at December 31, 2016, compared to $13,389 million at December 31, 2015, as shown in the Common equity tier 1 capital row of the table; The calculations of Common equity tier 1 capital, Tier 1 capital, and Tier 2 capital include phase-out periods for certain instruments from January 2015 through December 2017 The primary items subject to the phase-out from capital for us are other intangible assets, deferred tax assets that arise from tax loss and credit carryforwards, and trust preferred securities Risk-weighted assets under the Basel III Standardized Approach are generally based on supervisory risk weightings that vary only by counterparty type and asset class

#The credit quality of newly originated loans in 2018 was strong overall, as evidenced by a weighted-average LTV on originations of 67% and a weighted-average FICO score of 773 The credit performance of the majority of the home equity portfolio where we hold the first lien position is superior to the portion of the portfolio where we hold the second lien position but do not hold the first lien; This information is used for internal reporting and risk management, where we also segment the population into pools based on product type, such as home equity loans, brokered home equity loans, home equity lines of credit, and brokered home equity lines of credit As part of our overall risk analysis and monitoring, we segment the portfolio based on loan delinquency, nonperforming status, modification and bankruptcy status, FICO scores, LTV, lien position, and geographic concentration The portfolio is primarily originated within markets located in the Mid-Atlantic, Midwest, and Southeast, with less than 5% of the portfolio in states outside of those markets as of December 31, 2018; //As of December 31, 2018, the total commercial lending commitments amounted to $120,165 million, which is an increase from $112,125 million as of December 31, 2017 The home equity lines of credit commitments were $16,944 million as of December 31, 2018, showing a decrease from $17,852 million in the previous year The credit card commitments reached $27,100 million as of December 31, 2018, up from $24,911 million as of December 31, 2017; Additionally, loss mitigation activities have been intensified, underwriting standards tightened, and pricing actions implemented to address elevated risks associated with the home equity portfolio The following table presents the geographic distribution of consumer credit outstandings by product as of December 31, 2007, and 2006 In the top 12 states, California had home equity loans of $14; As of December 31, 2018, home equity loans comprised $15,500 million of primarily variable-rate home equity lines of credit and $10,600 million of closed-end home equity installment loans In comparison, as of December 31, 2017, the amounts were $16,800 million and $11,600 million, respectively We monitor borrower performance monthly, including obtaining original loan-to-value ratios (LTV), updated FICO scores at least quarterly, updated LTVs at least semi-annually, and other credit metrics at least quarterly, including the historical performance of any related mortgage loans regardless of lien position that we do or do not hold; 0 billion to the Allowance for loan losses for the year ended December 31, 2007, as risk-layered loans, continued weak housing prices, and slowing economic growth led to a significant rise in nonperforming assets and estimated losses, particularly concerning recently originated high loan-to-value loans in regions with substantial declines in housing prices The decline in housing prices, combined with the second lien position of these loans, results in minimal proceeds upon foreclosure, exacerbating the severity of losses Although subprime Home equity loans do not constitute a significant portion of the Home equity loan balance, the origination of subprime home equity loans was halted in the third quarter of 2007

#For the first and second-lien mortgage sold portfolio, we have established an indemnification and repurchase liability pursuant to investor sale agreements based on claims made, demand patterns observed to date and/or expected in the future, and our estimate of future claims on a loan-by-loan basis To estimate the mortgage repurchase liability arising from breaches of representations and warranties, we consider the following factors: (i) borrower performance in our historically sold portfolio (both actual and estimated future defaults), (ii) the level of outstanding unresolved repurchase claims, (iii) estimated probable future repurchase claims, considering information about file requests, delinquent and liquidated loans, resolved and unresolved mortgage insurance rescission notices, and our historical experience with claim rescissions, (iv) the potential ability to cure the defects identified in the repurchase claims (“rescission rate”), and (v) the estimated severity of loss upon repurchase of the loan or collateral, make-whole settlement, or indemnification See Note 24 Commitments and Guarantees in the Notes To Consolidated Financial Statements in Item 8 of this Report for additional information; In 2006, we did not make any unregistered sales of equity securities; , contractual loss caps, statutes of limitations) Origination and sale of residential mortgages is an ongoing business activity, and, accordingly, management continually assesses the need to recognize indemnification and repurchase liabilities pursuant to the associated investor sale agreements We establish indemnification and repurchase liabilities for estimated losses on sold first and second-lien mortgages for which indemnification is expected to be provided or for loans that are expected to be repurchased; //Indemnification and repurchase claims are typically settled on an individual loan basis through make-whole payments or loan repurchases; however, on occasion, we may negotiate pooled settlements with investors In connection with pooled settlements, we typically do not repurchase loans, and the consummation of such transactions generally results in us no longer having indemnification and repurchase exposure with the investor in the transaction For the first and second-lien mortgage balances of unresolved and settled claims contained in the tables below, a significant amount of these claims were associated with sold loans originated through correspondent lender and broker origination channels; Overall, we repurchased a total of 2,226,300 shares of our common stock during the quarter ended December 31, 2006 Since the inception of the share repurchase program approved by our Board of Directors in October 2002, which allows for the repurchase of up to 23 million shares, an additional 85 million shares have been authorized for repurchase under the program As of December 31, 2006, we had repurchased a total of 73,669,912 shares under the program; The following tables present the unpaid principal balance of repurchase claims by vintage and total unresolved repurchase claims for the past five quarters
#During the first and second quarters of 2011, the company entered into a number of interest rate lock agreements with an aggregate notional amount of $725 0 million, with fixed interest rates ranging from 3 10% to 4; Under the swap agreements, the company paid interest at floating rates based on changes in LIBOR and received interest at a fixed rate of 6 75% The company reduced interest expense by $5; 5 million over the next twelve months as a yield adjustment to its senior notes The effective portion of the interest rate locks amortized as a net increase to interest expense during the years ended December 31, 2012, 2011, and 2010 was $2 2 million, $1; From time to time, the company enters into treasury and interest rate locks to manage exposure to fluctuations in interest rates in anticipation of future debt issuances, and these transactions are accounted for as cash flow hedges As of December 31, 2012, and 2011, no interest rate lock cash flow hedges were outstanding During the second quarter of 2012, the company entered into a number of interest rate lock agreements with an aggregate notional amount of $200; 1 million and $0 3 million, respectively, reclassified from other comprehensive loss to earnings) for 2012 and 2011, and are included in "accumulated other comprehensive loss" A summary of our financial liabilities that are measured at fair value on a recurring basis, by level within the fair value hierarchy is as follows: As of December 31, 2012, the fair value of interest rate swaps at Level 1 was $0, at Level 2 was $12,388, at Level 3 was $0, and the total was $12,388; 4 million and $8 5 million due to periodic settlements of active swap agreements during the years ended December 31, 2011, and 2010, respectively As of December 31, 2012, and 2011, the company had no interest rate swap agreements outstanding

#As of December 31, 2013, future development costs estimated to be required for the development of proved undeveloped liquid hydrocarbon, natural gas, and synthetic crude oil reserves related to continuing operations for the years 2014 through 2018 are projected to be $2,894 million, $2,567 million, $2,020 million, $1,452 million, and $575 million The timing of future projects and estimated future development costs relating to the development of proved undeveloped liquid hydrocarbon, natural gas, and synthetic crude oil reserves are forward-looking statements based on a number of assumptions, including commodity prices, presently known physical data concerning the size and character of the reservoirs, economic recoverability, technology developments, future drilling success, industry economic conditions, levels of cash flow from operations, production experience, and other operating considerations To the extent these assumptions prove inaccurate, actual recoveries, timing, and development costs could differ from current estimates; Transfers from proved undeveloped to proved developed reserves included 57 mmboe in the Eagle Ford, 18 mmboe in the Bakken, and 7 mmboe in the Oklahoma resource basins due to producing wells Costs incurred in 2013, 2012, and 2011 for the development of proved undeveloped reserves were $2,536 million, $1,995 million, and $1,107 million, respectively A total of 59 mmboe was booked as a result of reliable technology, which included statistical analysis of production performance, decline curve analysis, rate transient analysis, reservoir simulation, and volumetric analysis; The statistical nature of production performance, combined with highly certain reservoir continuity or quality within the reliable technology areas and sufficient proved undeveloped locations, establishes the reasonable certainty criteria required for booking reserves Projects can remain in proved undeveloped reserves for extended periods in certain situations, such as large development projects that take more than five years to complete or the timing of when additional gas compression is needed Of the 627 mmboe of proved undeveloped reserves at December 31, 2013, 24 percent of the volume is associated with projects that have been included in proved reserves for more than five years; The purchases of reserves in place added 16 mmboe Extensions, discoveries, and other additions accounted for an increase of 142 mmboe Dispositions led to a decrease of 4 mmboe; //At the beginning of the year, the total proved reserves were 728 mmboe The revisions of previous estimates resulted in a decrease of 223 mmboe, largely due to reductions in the capital development program that deferred proved undeveloped reserves beyond the 5-year plan There was an improved recovery of 1 mmboe; Transfers to proved developed reserves resulted in a decrease of 79 mmboe, which included 47 mmboe from the Eagle Ford, 14 mmboe from the Bakken, and 5 mmboe from the Oklahoma Resource Basins due to development drilling and completions By the end of the year, the total proved reserves stood at 603 mmboe

#Prior to the acquisition of Countrywide on July 1, 2008, the company did not originate or service significant subprime residential mortgage loans, nor did it hold a significant amount of beneficial interests in QSPEs of subprime residential mortgage loans; As of December 31, 2008, the principal balance of beneficial interests issued by QSPEs holding subprime ARMs amounted to $56 5 billion, with the fair value of beneficial interests related to those QSPEs held by the Corporation totaling $14 million A summary of loans in QSPEs holding subprime ARMs, along with workout and payoff activity by ASF categorization for the six months ending December 31, 2008, is presented in the accompanying table; Prior to the acquisition of Countrywide, the company did not originate or service significant subprime residential mortgage loans, nor did it hold a substantial amount of beneficial interest in QSPEs of such loans In October 2008, an agreement with several state attorneys general led to the announcement of the Countrywide National Homeownership Retention Program, which aims to systematically identify and offer loan modifications to eligible Countrywide subprime and pay option ARM borrowers whose loans are in delinquency or facing interest rate or payment changes For further details on loan modification programs, refer to Recent Events on page 22; In January 2008, the SEC's Office of the Chief Accountant issued a letter addressing accounting issues related to the ASF Framework, concluding that the SEC would not object to continuing off-balance sheet accounting treatment for Segment 2 loans modified under the framework For current loans modified outside the ASF Framework, servicers must conduct individual analyses to demonstrate the borrower's probable inability to meet repayment obligations in the near term, providing sufficient evidence of imminent or reasonably foreseeable default A prior letter from the SEC's Office of the Chief Accountant in July 2007 also indicated that off-balance sheet accounting treatment for these loans would not be objected to; As of December 31, 2009, the principal balance of beneficial interests issued by the QSPEs holding subprime ARMs amounted to $70 5 billion, with the fair value of beneficial interests related to those QSPEs held by the Corporation totaling $9 million A summary of loans in QSPEs holding subprime ARMs as of December 31, 2009, along with workout and other activities for subprime loans categorized by ASF for 2009, is presented in the following table; In January 2008, the SEC’s Office of the Chief Accountant issued a letter addressing accounting issues related to the ASF Framework, concluding that the SEC would not object to continuing off-balance sheet accounting treatment for Segment 2 loans modified under the framework For current loans modified outside of the ASF Framework, the servicer must conduct an individual analysis to demonstrate the borrower's probable inability to meet repayment obligations in the near term, providing evidence of imminent or foreseeable default In July 2007, the SEC’s Office of the Chief Accountant issued a letter stating it would not object to continuing off-balance sheet accounting treatment for these loans

#Our fuel surcharge programs generated freight revenues of $2 6 billion in 2013, $2 6 billion in 2012, and $2; Other revenues include earnings from our subsidiaries, revenues from commuter rail operations, and accessorial revenues, which are earned when customers retain equipment owned or controlled by us or when we perform additional services such as switching or storage We recognize other revenues as we perform services or meet contractual obligations In 2013, freight revenues from five of our six commodity groups increased compared to 2012, although revenue from agricultural products saw a slight decline; We generate freight revenues by transporting freight or other materials from our six commodity groups, and these revenues vary with volume (carloads) and Average Revenue per Carload (ARC) Changes in price, traffic mix, and fuel surcharges drive the ARC, and we provide some customers with contractual incentives for meeting or exceeding specified cumulative volumes or shipping to and from specific locations, which we record as reductions to freight revenues based on actual or projected future shipments Freight revenues are recognized as shipments move from origin to destination, and we allocate these revenues between reporting periods based on the relative transit time in each reporting period, recognizing expenses as they are incurred; //In the category of Operating Revenues, the Freight revenues for the year 2013 amounted to $20,684 million, which represents a 5% increase compared to the $19,686 million recorded in 2012, and a 6% increase from the $18,508 million in 2011 The Other revenues for 2013 totaled $1,279 million, reflecting a 3% increase from $1,240 million in 2012, and an 18% increase from $1,049 million in 2011 The Total revenues for 2013 reached $21,963 million, which is a 5% increase from the $20,926 million in 2012, and a 7% increase from the $19,557 million in 2011; In 2013, other revenue increased from 2012 primarily due to miscellaneous contract revenue and higher revenues at our subsidiaries that broker intermodal and automotive services In 2012, other revenues increased from 2011 mainly due to higher revenues at our subsidiaries that broker intermodal and automotive services, with assessorial revenues also increasing in 2012 due to container revenue related to a rise in intermodal shipments; 2 billion in 2011 The fuel surcharge in 2013 was essentially flat compared to 2012, as lower fuel prices offset improved fuel recovery provisions and the lag effect of our programs Rising fuel prices and an increase in shipments subject to fuel surcharges drove the increase from 2011 to 2012

#//The table outlines the components of net periodic benefit cost for Pension and Other Postretirement Benefits for the years ended December 31, 2008, 2007, and 2006 In the category of Pension for the year 2008, the service cost amounted to $952, the interest cost was $2,823, the expected return on plan assets was -$3,811, the amortization of prior service costs was $206, the recognized net actuarial loss was $392, and the net periodic benefit cost totaled $562 The net periodic benefit cost included in Earnings from operations for Pension in 2008 was $696; //In the context of Pension and Other Postretirement Net Periodic Benefit Cost, the net periodic pension cost is comprised of several components Firstly, the Service Cost, which is the increase in the projected pension benefit obligation resulting from benefits payable to employees of the Subsidiaries for the service rendered during the current year Secondly, the Interest Cost on the Liability, which represents the time value adjustment on the projected pension benefit obligation at the end of each year; The net periodic benefit cost included in Earnings from operations for Pension in 2006 was $746 For Other Postretirement Benefits in 2008, the service cost was $126, the interest cost was $459, the expected return on plan assets was -$8, the amortization of prior service costs was -$93, the recognized net actuarial loss was $86, and the net periodic benefit cost was $570 The net periodic benefit cost included in Earnings from operations for Other Postretirement Benefits in 2008 was $507; For the year 2007, the service cost for Pension was $953, the interest cost was $2,681, the expected return on plan assets was -$3,507, the amortization of prior service costs was $200, the recognized net actuarial loss was $764, and the net periodic benefit cost was $1,101 The net periodic benefit cost included in Earnings from operations for Pension in 2007 was $1,082 In 2006, the service cost for Pension was $908, the interest cost was $2,497, the expected return on plan assets was -$3,455, the amortization of prior service costs was $188, the recognized net actuarial loss was $912, and the net periodic benefit cost was $1,050; Lastly, the Amortization of Net Actuarial Gains or Losses, which arise from differences between the actual experience and the expected experience on pension plan assets or projected pension benefit obligation during a particular period These gains and losses are accumulated and, if they exceed 10% of the greater of the projected pension benefit obligation or the market-related value of plan assets, they are amortized into pension expense over the expected service years of the employees In 2007, the Subsidiaries recognized a pension expense of $98 million, which was a decrease compared to $180 million in 2006 and $146 million in 2005; The net periodic benefit cost included in Earnings from operations for Other Postretirement Benefits in 2006 was $481 Additionally, a portion of the net periodic benefit cost is allocated to production as product costs and may remain in inventory at the end of each reporting period

During fiscal years 2011, 2010, and 2009, borrowing needs in our Canadian operations were funded by corporate borrowings in the U S To mitigate the foreign currency exchange rate risk, we used foreign exchange forward contracts, and we do not enter into forward contracts for speculative purposes; As of December 31, 2009, the fair value of our foreign currency forward contracts was $0 3 million, compared to $1 2 million as of December 31, 2008; Since 2007, we have utilized foreign currency forward contracts to mitigate the risk from exchange rate fluctuations on inter-company transactions and projected inventory purchases for our Canadian subsidiary Beginning in December 2008, we also started using foreign currency forward contracts to reduce the risk associated with foreign currency exchange rate fluctuations on inter-company transactions for our European subsidiary It is important to note that we do not enter into derivative financial instruments for speculative or trading purposes; #e , the year the loans were sold) based on a combination of historical trends and forecasted repurchases and losses considering the: (1) trends in requests by investors for loan documentation packages to be reviewed; (2) trends in recent repurchases and make-wholes; (3) historical percentage of claims made as a percentage of loan documentation package requests; (4) success rate in appealing claims; (5) inventory of unresolved claims; and (6) estimated loss given repurchase or make-whole, including the loss of principal, accrued interest, and foreclosure costs The Company does not change its estimation methodology by counterparty, but the historical experience and trends are considered when evaluating the overall reserve; Payments to make the investor whole are also treated as utilizations and charged directly against the reserve The provision for estimated probable losses arising from loan sales is recorded as an adjustment to the gain on sale, which is included in Other revenue in the Consolidated Statement of Income A liability for representations and warranties is estimated when the Company sells loans and is updated quarterly; These factors contributed to a $493 million change in estimate for this reserve in 2009 As indicated above, the repurchase reserve is calculated by sales vintage The majority of the repurchases in 2009 were from the 2006 and 2007 sales vintages, which also represent the vintages with the largest loss-given-repurchase; //The Share Repurchase Plan states that on April 23, 2008, the board of directors authorized a new share repurchase program of up to $1 5 billion with no stated expiration date During the year ended December 31, 2009, there were no purchases under this program, while on December 31, 2008, 5; An insignificant percentage of 2009 repurchases were from vintages prior to 2006, and this is expected to decrease, because those vintages are later in the credit cycle Although early in the credit cycle, the Company has experienced improved repurchase and loss-given-repurchase statistics from the 2008 and 2009 vintages In the case of a repurchase of a credit-impaired SOP 03-3 loan (now incorporated into ASC 310-30), the difference between the loan’s fair value and unpaid principal balance at the time of the repurchase is recorded as a utilization of the repurchase reserve; Any subsequent adjustment to the provision is recorded in Other revenue in the Consolidated Statement of Income The activity in the repurchase reserve for the years ended December 31, 2009 and 2008 is as follows:

#The total gross carried claim and claim adjustment expense reserves were 16,799 million dollars in 2015, down from 17,184 million dollars in 2014 The net case reserves were 6,992 million dollars in 2015, while they were 7,474 million dollars in 2014 The net IBNR reserves were 8,371 million dollars in 2015, compared to 8,295 million dollars in 2014; The Uncollectible reinsurance category shows a negative amount of $30, and the Other reserve re-estimates, net category has a total of $24, which includes $10 from Commercial Lines, $4 from Personal Lines, and $10 from Property & Casualty Other Operations The Total prior accident year development across all categories is positive $457, with $28 from Commercial Lines, $151 from Personal Lines, and $278 from Property & Casualty Other Operations During 2016, the Company’s re-estimates of prior accident year reserves included significant reserve changes; The Company also records reserves for group term life, accidental death & dismemberment, short-term disability, and other group products with short claim payout periods For these products, reserves are determined using paid or reported actuarial development methods, producing a completion pattern and estimate of ultimate loss IBNR for these lines of business equals the estimated ultimate losses and loss adjustment expenses less the amount of paid or reported claims, depending on the method used; The Personal auto liability reserves increased, primarily related to increased bodily injury frequency and severity for the 2015 accident year, including for uninsured and under-insured motorist claims, and increased bodily injury severity for the 2014 accident year Increases in auto liability loss costs were observed across both the direct and agency distribution channels The Professional liability reserves decreased for claims made in years 2008 - 2013, primarily for large accounts, including non-securities class action cases, as claim costs emerged favorably with these years maturing, leading management to place more weight on the emerged experience; //The loss reserve development table for CNA Financial Corporation indicates that the cumulative ending balances should not be added, as the amount at the end of each calendar year includes activity for both the current and prior years For the year ended December 31, 2005, the originally reported gross reserves for unpaid claim and claim adjustment expenses amounted to 30,694 million dollars In 2006, this figure decreased to 29,459 million dollars, and it continued to decline to 22,663 million dollars by 2015; The Workers’ compensation reserves considered favorable emergence on reported losses for recent accident years, although there was a partially offsetting adverse impact due to two recent Florida Supreme Court rulings that increased the Company’s exposure to workers’ compensation claims in that state The favorable emergence was driven by lower frequency and, to a lesser extent, lower medical severity, and management placed additional weight on this favorable experience as it became more credible The General liability reserves increased for accident years 2012 - 2015 primarily due to higher severity losses incurred on a class of business that insures service and maintenance contractors, and also increased for accident years 2008 and 2010 due to indemnity losses and legal costs associated with a litigated claim

//The home equity loan portfolio, as of December 31, 2014, totaled $34 7 billion, which represents 17% of the total loan portfolio Within this portfolio, $20; As of December 31, 2014, we held an originated first lien position for about 51% of the total portfolio, and for those originated as a second lien, we currently hold or service the first lien position for an additional 2% of the portfolio The remaining 47% of the portfolio was secured by second liens where we do not hold the first lien position The credit performance of the majority of the home equity portfolio, where we are in, hold, or service the first lien position, is superior to the portion of the portfolio where we hold the second lien position but do not hold the first lien; The total for the interest-only product is $10,349, and for the principal and interest product, it is $7,778 This total includes all home equity lines of credit that mature in 2015 or later, including those with borrowers where we have terminated borrowing privileges Additionally, it includes approximately $154 million, $48 million, $57 million, $42 million, and $564 million of home equity lines of credit with balloon payments, including those where we have terminated borrowing privileges, with draw periods scheduled to end in 2015, 2016, 2017, 2018, and 2019 and thereafter, respectively; For internal reporting and risk management, we also segment the population into pools based on product type, such as home equity loans, brokered home equity loans, home equity lines of credit, and brokered home equity lines of credit As part of our overall risk analysis and monitoring, we segment the home equity portfolio based on the delinquency, modification status, and bankruptcy status of these loans, as well as the delinquency, modification status, and bankruptcy status of any mortgage loan with the same borrower, regardless of whether it is a first lien senior to our second lien In establishing our allowance for loan and lease losses (ALLL) for non-impaired loans, we primarily utilize a delinquency roll-rate methodology for pools of loans; //Home equity lending includes both home equity loans and lines-of-credit, which are secured by a first-lien or junior-lien on the borrower’s residence, allowing customers to borrow against the equity in their home or refinance existing mortgage debt Home equity products include closed-end loans that are generally fixed-rate with principal and interest payments, and variable-rate, interest-only lines-of-credit that do not require payment of principal during the 10-year revolving period The home equity line of credit may convert to a 20-year amortizing structure at the end of the revolving period, and applications are underwritten centrally in conjunction with an automated underwriting system

#//In the context of Provision for Income Taxes, the Company’s effective tax rates were 30% for the years ended September 27, 2008, and September 29, 2007, and 29% for the year ended September 30, 2006 The Company’s effective rates differ from the statutory federal income tax rate of 35% due primarily to certain undistributed foreign earnings for which no U S; In China, one of the Company’s entities had a tax holiday that provided for a zero percent tax rate in 2008 For the years 2009 through 2011, the Company’s tax rate is 50% of the statutory rate, or 12 5% based on the 2010 statutory rate of 25%; 5% for 2008, 2009, and 2010 forward, respectively In general, companies must pay the higher of the income tax or the IETU, although the IETU is not creditable against future income tax liabilities; Equity income and dividends resulted in a reduction of $41 million for the year ended December 31, 2010, a reduction of $20 million for the year ended December 31, 2009, and a reduction of $17 million for the year ended December 31, 2008 The (income) expense not resulting in tax impact was $8 million for the year ended December 31, 2010, $4 million for the year ended December 31, 2009, and $18 million for the year ended December 31, 2008 The US tax effect of foreign earnings and dividends was $28 million for the year ended December 31, 2010, $10 million for the year ended December 31, 2009, and a negative $5 million for the year ended December 31, 2008; Effective January 1, 2008, the bill repealed the existing asset-based tax and established a dual income tax system consisting of a new minimum flat tax (the “IETU”) and the existing regular income tax system The IETU system taxes companies on cash basis net income, consisting only of certain specified items of revenue and expense, at rates of 16 5%, 17%, and 17; Other foreign tax rate differentials resulted in a reduction of $48 million for the year ended December 31, 2010, a reduction of $15 million for the year ended December 31, 2009, and a reduction of $84 million for the year ended December 31, 2008 Legislative changes resulted in a reduction of $71 million for the year ended December 31, 2010, an increase of $71 million for the year ended December 31, 2009, and an increase of $3 million for the year ended December 31, 2008 Tax-deductible interest on foreign equity investments and other related items resulted in a reduction of $3 million for the year ended December 31, 2010, a reduction of $76 million for the year ended December 31, 2009, and no impact for the year ended December 31, 2008

#//For the year ended December 31, 2015, the performance share unit awards had no shares outstanding at January 1, with a weighted-average grant date fair value of $0 During the same year, 10,705 shares were granted at a weighted-average grant date fair value of $178 84; 20 The Performance Share amounts above represent aggregate initial target awards and do not reflect potential increases or decreases resulting from the final performance factor to be determined at the end of the respective performance period As of December 31, 2007, the three-year performance period for the 2005 Performance Share grants was completed; Accordingly, the fair value of Performance Shares is based upon the closing price of the Holding Company’s common stock on the date of grant, reduced by the present value of estimated dividends to be paid on that stock during the performance period Compensation expense related to initial Performance Shares granted prior to January 1, 2006 and expected to vest is recognized ratably during the performance period Compensation expense related to initial Performance Shares granted on or after January 1, 2006 and expected to vest is recognized ratably over the performance period or the period to retirement eligibility, if shorter; Performance Shares expected to vest and the related compensation expenses may be further adjusted by the performance factor most likely to be achieved, as estimated by management, at the end of the performance period Compensation expense of $90 million, $74 million, and $24 million related to Performance Shares was recognized for the years ended December 31, 2007, 2006, and 2005, respectively As of December 31, 2007, there were $57 million of total unrecognized compensation costs related to Performance Share awards; Included in the immediately preceding table are 965,525 outstanding Performance Shares to which the final performance factor will be applied The calculation of the performance factor is expected to be finalized during the second quarter of 2008 after all data necessary to perform the calculation is publicly available Performance Share awards are accounted for as equity awards but are not credited with dividend-equivalents for actual dividends paid on the Holding Company’s common stock during the performance period; //The cell under the "Backlog" row and "Firm" column states that firm backlog represents orders for products and services where no contingencies remain before we and the customer are required to perform The cell under the "Backlog" row and "Definition" column explains that backlog does not include prospective orders where customer-controlled contingencies remain, such as the customers receiving approval from their Board of Directors, shareholders, or government and completing financing arrangements The cell under the "Backlog" row and "Conditions" column mentions that all such contingencies must be satisfied or have expired prior to recording a new firm order even if satisfying such conditions is highly certain; The cell under the "Backlog" row and "BDS Total" column states that BDS total backlog increased by 19% in 2012, from $60,041 million to $71,475 million, primarily due to F-15 and C-17 orders and the contract award for the Space Launch System program received in 2012 The cell under the "Backlog" row and "Further Details" column suggests that for further details on the changes between periods, refer to the discussions of the individual segments below; The cell under the "Backlog" row and "Order Status" column explains that however, once orders are included in firm backlog, orders remain in backlog until canceled or fulfilled, although the value of orders is adjusted as changes to price and schedule are agreed to with customers The cell under the "Backlog" row and "2012 Increase" column notes that the increase in contractual backlog during 2012 was due to orders in excess of deliveries, partially reduced by cancellations of orders and changes in projected revenue escalation The cell under the "Backlog" row and "2012 Decrease" column states that the decrease in unobligated backlog in 2012 was due to incremental funding of the existing multi-year contract for Commercial Airplanes’ share of the USAF contract for the KC-46A Tanker; The cell under the "Backlog" row and "Exclusions" column clarifies that firm orders exclude options The cell under the "Backlog" row and "Customer Remedies" column indicates that a number of our customers may have contractual remedies that may be implicated by program delays The cell under the "Backlog" row and "Claims" column states that we continue to address customer claims and requests for other contractual relief as they arise

#The overall Total for Pension Benefits is $3,471, and for Other Postretirement Benefits, it is $218 The Company's stock-based compensation plans are described in detail, indicating that shares issued in satisfaction of stock-based compensation may come from authorized but unissued shares, shares held by the Company in treasury, or shares purchased in the open market In the years 2016, 2015, and 2014, the Company issued shares from treasury to satisfy stock-based compensation; All derivatives are recognized on the balance sheet at fair value On the date the derivative contract is entered into, the Company may designate the derivative as a hedge of the fair value of a recognized asset or liability (fair-value hedge) or a hedge of a forecasted transaction or of the variability of cash flows to be received or paid related to a recognized asset or liability (cash-flow hedge) Changes in the fair value of a fair-value hedge, along with the gain or loss on the underlying hedged item, are recorded in current-period earnings; #//In the year 2005, the Non-Utility Nuclear sector had 13% of its bundled capacity and energy contracts sold forward In 2005, 58% of capacity contracts were sold forward, leading to a total of 71% of capacity sold forward The planned net megawatts in operation for Non-Utility Nuclear in 2005 was 4,155 MW; The Vermont Yankee power plant, located in Vernon, VT, is part of the IS0-NE market, was commissioned in 1972, acquired in July 2002, has a capacity of 605 MW with a Boiling Water reactor type, and its license will expire in 2032 Lastly, the Palisades power plant, situated in South Haven, MI, is part of the MISO market, was commissioned in 1971, acquired in April 2007, has a capacity of 811 MW with a Pressurized Water reactor type, and its license will expire in 2031 Entergy Wholesale Commodities also owns two non-operating nuclear facilities, Big Rock Point in Michigan and Indian Point 1 in New York, which were acquired when Entergy purchased the Palisades and Indian Point 2 nuclear plants, respectively; The FitzPatrick power plant, situated in Oswego, NY, is part of the NYISO market, was commissioned in 1975, acquired in November 2000, has a capacity of 838 MW with a Boiling Water reactor type, and its license will expire in 2034 The Indian Point 3 power plant, located in Buchanan, NY, is also part of the NYISO market, was commissioned in 1976, acquired in November 2000, has a capacity of 1,041 MW with a Pressurized Water reactor type, and its license expired in 2015 The Indian Point 2 power plant, also in Buchanan, NY, is part of the NYISO market, was commissioned in 1974, acquired in September 2001, has a capacity of 1,028 MW with a Pressurized Water reactor type, and its license expired in 2013; In 2008, the Non-Utility Nuclear sector still had 13% of its bundled capacity and energy contracts sold forward The percentage of capacity contracts sold forward further decreased to 22%, resulting in a total of 35% of capacity sold forward The planned net megawatts in operation for Non-Utility Nuclear continued to be 4,200 MW; In 2007, the Non-Utility Nuclear sector continued with 13% of its bundled capacity and energy contracts sold forward However, the percentage of capacity contracts sold forward dropped to 36%, leading to a total of 49% of capacity sold forward The planned net megawatts in operation for Non-Utility Nuclear remained at 4,200 MW; Additionally, Entergy Wholesale Commodities offers operations and management services, including decommissioning services, to nuclear power plants owned by other utilities across the United States Furthermore, Entergy Wholesale Commodities includes ownership or participation in joint ventures that own non-nuclear power plants and the sale of electric power produced by these plants to wholesale customers Under the Property Nuclear Generating Stations section, Entergy Wholesale Commodities owns the following nuclear power plants: The Pilgrim power plant, located in Plymouth, MA, is part of the IS0-NE market, was commissioned in 1972, acquired in July 1999, has a capacity of 688 MW with a Boiling Water reactor type, and its license expired in 2012

#//For the year ended December 31, 2009, the net cash provided by operating activities was $362 7 million, while in 2008 it was $525 5 million, and in 2007 it was $915; 2 million in 2009, $915 8 million in 2008, and $778 9 million in 2007; 7 million in 2009, -$666 4 million in 2008, and -$740 8 million in 2007; Consequently, the increase in cash and cash equivalents for the year ended December 31, 2009, was $159 6 million, while there was a decrease of -$239 3 million in 2008 and an increase of $126; 4 million in 2008, and -$48 2 million in 2007 Regarding financing activities, the net cash outflow was -$100; The increased inventory is attributed to the higher cost of natural gas and an increase in storage contracts Additionally, the increase in net regulatory assets and liabilities is linked to a rise in pension funding obligations and a decrease in the fair value of investments in the decommissioning fund, although this was partially offset by a decrease in the asset retirement obligation due to the extended life of the nuclear facilities On the other hand, cash provided by operating activities for discontinued operations saw a decrease of $75 million, primarily because of reduced income taxes received during 2008
#Warranty obligations incurred in connection with long-term production contracts are accounted for within the contract estimates at completion (EACs) Our other warranty obligations, primarily for business jet aircraft, are included in other current liabilities and other liabilities on the Consolidated Balance Sheet The changes in the carrying amount of warranty liabilities for each of the past three years were as follows:; //In the context of Accrued Warranty and Indemnifications, the Company offers a basic limited parts and labor warranty on its hardware products The basic warranty period for hardware products is typically one year from the date of purchase by the end-user Additionally, the Company provides a 90-day basic warranty for its service parts used to repair the Company’s hardware products; The Company currently accounts for the estimated cost that may be incurred under its basic limited product warranties at the time related revenue is recognized When determining appropriate accruals for product warranty obligations, the Company considers factors such as the size of the installed base of products subject to warranty protection, historical and projected warranty claim rates, historical and projected cost-per-claim, and knowledge of specific product failures that are outside of the Company’s typical experience The Company also assesses the adequacy of its preexisting warranty liabilities and adjusts the amounts as necessary based on actual experience and changes in future estimates; //In the context of Product Warranties, we provide warranties to our customers associated with certain product sales, which have a material impact on our results of operations, financial condition, or cash flows We record estimated warranty costs in the period in which the related products are delivered The warranty liability recorded at each balance sheet date is based on the number of months of warranty coverage remaining for products delivered and the average historical monthly warranty payments; The estimated cost to develop such updates is accounted for as warranty costs that are recognized at the time related software revenue is recognized Factors considered in determining appropriate accruals related to such updates include the number of units delivered, the number of updates expected to occur, and the historical cost and estimated future cost of the resources necessary to develop these updates; For products accounted for under subscription accounting pursuant to SOP No 97-2, the Company recognizes warranty expense as incurred Furthermore, the Company periodically provides updates to its applications and system software to maintain the software’s compliance with specifications
#The maximum lending limits for accounts receivable factoring arrangements stood at $697,702 thousand in 2010, compared to $535,257 thousand in 2009 Furthermore, the reserve for unfunded credit commitments was $17,414 thousand in 2010, an increase from $13,331 thousand in 2009 It is important to note that the commitments available for funding represent those where clients have met all necessary collateral, compliance, and financial covenants as required under loan commitment agreements; 2 billion of syndications, assignments, and participations primarily to financial institutions, while the comparable amount at December 31, 2010, was $16 7 billion Commitments generally have fixed expiration dates, may require payment of a fee, and contain termination clauses if the customer's credit quality deteriorates; Conversely, the commitments unavailable for funding are those where clients have failed to meet these requirements The maximum lending limits for accounts receivable factoring arrangements indicate the credit extended based on the creditworthiness of clients' sales invoices The potential exposure to credit loss for these commitments is equivalent to the contractual amount of the available unused loan commitment; Comparatively, as of December 31, 2010, commercial and commercial real estate commitments were $59,256, home equity lines of credit were $19,172, credit card commitments were $14,725, and other commitments were $2,652, resulting in a total of $95,805 It is important to note that commitments to extend credit represent arrangements to lend funds or provide liquidity under specified contractual conditions As of December 31, 2011, the commercial commitments reported above exclude $20; The credit approval and monitoring process for extending credit commitments is consistent with that used for making loans Historically, the actual liquidity needs and credit risk have been lower than the contractual amount of commitments to extend credit, as a significant portion of these commitments expire without being drawn upon Each potential borrower is evaluated individually, considering the necessary collateral, which may include real property, intellectual property, bank deposits, or business and personal assets; #The total loan and lease portfolio is segregated by the type of collateral securing the loan or lease, and the changes in the collateral composition from December 31, 2014, are consistent with the portfolio growth metrics, with increases noted; The underwriting for the floating rate lines of credit also incorporates a stress analysis for a rising interest rate, which is an additional consideration in the underwriting process for Home equity lending; //Home equity lending includes both home equity loans and lines-of-credit, which are secured by a first-lien or junior-lien on the borrower’s residence, allowing customers to borrow against the equity in their home or refinance existing mortgage debt Home equity products include closed-end loans that are generally fixed-rate with principal and interest payments, and variable-rate, interest-only lines-of-credit that do not require payment of principal during the 10-year revolving period The home equity line of credit may convert to a 20-year amortizing structure at the end of the revolving period, and applications are underwritten centrally in conjunction with an automated underwriting system; Huntington has not originated or acquired residential mortgages that allow negative amortization or allow the borrower multiple payment options Other consumer loans primarily consist of consumer loans not secured by real estate, including personal unsecured loans, overdraft balances, and credit cards The total loan and lease portfolio composition at December 31 shows that commercial and industrial loans amount to $20,560 million, representing 41% of the total; The home equity underwriting criteria is based on minimum credit scores, debt-to-income ratios, and LTV ratios, with current collateral valuations, while the underwriting for the floating rate lines of credit also incorporates a stress analysis for a rising interest rate Residential mortgage loans represent loans to consumers for the purchase or refinance of a residence, generally financed over a 15-year to 30-year term, and are extended to borrowers to finance their primary residence Applications for residential mortgages are underwritten centrally using consistent credit policies and processes, and all residential mortgage loan decisions utilize a full appraisal for collateral valuation; The commercial real estate construction loans total $1,031 million, which is 2% of the total, while commercial loans amount to $4,237 million, representing 8% of the total The total for commercial real estate is $5,268 million, which is 10% of the total, and the total commercial loans amount to $25,828 million, representing 51% of the total In the consumer category, automobile loans total $9,481 million, which is 19% of the total, while home equity loans amount to $8,471 million, representing 17% of the total
