During 2016, the Corporation deconsolidated agency residential mortgage securitization vehicles with total assets of $3 8 billion and total liabilities of $628 million following the sale of retained interests to third parties, after which the Corporation no longer had the unilateral ability to liquidate the vehicles Of the balances deconsolidated in 2016, $706 million of assets and $628 million of liabilities represent non-cash investing and financing activities and, accordingly, are not reflected on the Consolidated Statement of Cash Flows; The Corporation had liquidity commitments, including written put options and collateral value guarantees, with certain unconsolidated VIEs of $218 million and $442 million at December 31, 2018, and 2017 As part of its mortgage banking activities, the Corporation securitizes a portion of the first-lien residential mortgage loans it originates or purchases from third parties, generally in the form of Residential Mortgage-Backed Securities (RMBS) guaranteed by government-sponsored enterprises, FNMA and FHLMC (collectively the GSEs), or the Government National Mortgage Association (GNMA) primarily in the case of FHA-insured and U S; //The Corporation transfers residential mortgage loans to securitizations sponsored by the GSEs or GNMA in the normal course of business and receives RMBS in exchange, which may then be sold into the market to third-party investors for cash proceeds A majority of the first-lien residential and commercial mortgage loans securitized are initially classified as LHFS and accounted for under the fair value option Gains recognized on these LHFS prior to securitization, which totaled $487 million, $750 million, and $715 million net of hedges during 2016, 2015, and 2014, respectively, are not included in the table above

//Assurant Solutions, which includes American Security Group operations acquired in 1980 and American Bankers Insurance Group acquired in 1999, has leadership positions or is aligned with clients who are leaders in creditor placed homeowners insurance, manufactured housing homeowners, credit related insurance products, debt protection administration, and warranty and extended service contracts The Specialty Property division focuses on creditor placed homeowners and manufactured housing homeowners insurance products and related services, as well as other insurance related products such as renters’ insurance, watercraft, and motorcycle property coverages In our Consumer Protection division, we are a low-cost provider of credit and debt protection administration services; In 2014, Assurant Solutions received cash dividends of $110 million from StoneRiver, while in 2013, they received $122 million The portions of these dividends that represented returns on their investment were $110 million in 2014 and $6 million in 2013, which are reported in cash flows from operating activities In the first quarter of 2013, Assurant Solutions acquired Open Solutions for a cash purchase price of $16 million, net of cash acquired, along with the assumption of approximately $960 million of debt, and sold Club Solutions for approximately $35 million in cash; In addition, we offer a variety of warranties and extended service contracts on consumer electronics, cellular phones, personal computers, appliances, and vehicles through clients domestically and internationally Assurant Solutions maintains a comprehensive client and transaction database, which we believe gives us a competitive advantage with respect to pricing, marketing, and projected claims development Additionally, our high level of integration with clients allows us to have current and accurate data on the performance of their underwriting, claims, fees earned, and commissions; Assurant Solutions provides Specialty Property Solutions, underwriting a variety of creditor-placed and voluntary homeowners insurance, as well as property coverages on manufactured housing, specialty automobiles, recreational vehicles, and leased and financed equipment They also offer complementary programs such as flood insurance, renters’ insurance, and various other property coverages Assurant Solutions is a leading provider of creditor-placed and other collateral protection insurance programs based on the number of loans serviced, which may include those that protect a lender’s interest in homes, manufactured homes, and automobiles

#//The table summarizes our outstanding foreign currency forward contracts, which are considered economic hedges to minimize income volatility resulting from the remeasurement of net monetary assets and payables denominated in a currency other than the functional currency The objective of these contracts is to offset the gain or loss from remeasurement with the gain or loss from the fair market valuation of the forward contract It is important to note that these derivative instruments are not designated as hedges under GAAP; The ineffective portion of the hedge, unrealized gain or loss, if any, is recognized in current income during the period of change, as described in the Foreign Exchange Rates section As of December 31, 2011, the amount we expect to reclassify from AOCL to income over the next year is an unrealized net loss of $6 million, as noted in the Foreign Exchange Rates section For the years ended December 31, 2011, and 2010, there were no circumstances that would have resulted in the discontinuance of a foreign currency cash flow hedge, as mentioned in the Foreign Exchange Rates section; //The Company uses derivative financial instruments for purposes of hedging exposures to fluctuations in interest rates, as stated in the Derivative Financial Instruments section We are exposed to financial risk resulting from volatility in foreign exchange rates, commodity prices, and interest rates, which is detailed in the Derivatives note This risk is closely monitored and managed through the use of financial derivative instruments, including foreign currency forward contracts, commodity swap contracts, and interest rate swaps; dollar forward contracts are designated and qualify for hedge accounting as of each period presented below The currencies in this table represent 98 percent and 97 percent of the notional amounts of contracts outstanding as of December 31, 2011, and 2010, as noted in the Foreign Exchange Rates section; According to our policies and procedures, financial derivatives are used expressly for hedging purposes, and under no circumstances are they used for speculative purposes When material, we adjust the value of our derivative contracts for counterparty or our credit risk, as mentioned in the Derivatives section As a result of our international business presence, we are exposed to foreign currency exchange risks, which is outlined in the Foreign Exchange Rates section; These foreign currency forward contracts are designated and qualify as foreign currency cash flow hedges under GAAP The effective portion of the unrealized gain or loss on the forward contract is deferred and reported as a component of “Accumulated other comprehensive loss” (AOCL) When the hedged forecasted transaction (sale or purchase) occurs, the unrealized gain or loss is reclassified into income in the same line item associated with the hedged transaction in the same period or periods during which the hedged transaction affects income

#//The costs between the cost of license revenue and the cost of maintenance and service revenue are based on the license and maintenance and service revenue reported The cost of license revenue includes costs related to products sold and software licensed, allocated operating costs related to product support and distribution costs, royalties paid to third-party vendors, and the amortization of capitalized research and development costs associated with software products that have reached technological feasibility The cost of maintenance and service revenue includes operating costs related to maintaining the infrastructure necessary to operate our services and training organization, as well as costs associated with the delivery of our consulting services, such as hotline and onsite support, production services, and documentation of maintenance updates; The increase in amortization of intangible assets for fiscal 2013 compared to fiscal 2012 was mainly due to the amortization of intangible assets acquired, which was partially offset by certain intangible assets reaching full amortization For a detailed schedule of future amortization amounts, please refer to Note 4 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements, which is incorporated by reference here; #If the results of the qualitative assessment are not conclusive, a quantitative goodwill test is performed The quantitative goodwill test consists of two steps: the first step compares the estimated fair value of each reporting unit with its estimated net book value, which includes goodwill and identifiable intangible assets If the reporting unit’s estimated fair value exceeds its estimated net book value, goodwill is not impaired; Changes in the estimates and assumptions used in our goodwill impairment testing could result in future impairment losses, which could be material Additionally, when a portion of a reporting unit is disposed, goodwill is allocated to the gain or loss on disposition based on the relative fair values of the business or businesses disposed and the portion of the reporting unit that will be retained When determining the fair value of the businesses disposed of and the reporting unit to be retained, we use estimates and assumptions similar to those used in our impairment analysis; If the estimated fair value of a reporting unit is less than its estimated net book value, the second step of the goodwill test is performed to measure the amount of impairment, if any An impairment is equal to the excess of the carrying amount of goodwill over its fair value During the fourth quarter of 2016, the firm assessed goodwill for impairment using a qualitative assessment; Therefore, the firm determined that goodwill for all reporting units was not impaired; During 2016, the firm’s net earnings, pre-tax margin, diluted earnings per common share, return on average common shareholders’ equity, and book value per common share increased compared to 2015 Additionally, the firm’s overall cost structure declined, reflecting the impact of expense savings initiatives The firm also evaluated firm and industry events, noting that there were no events, entity-specific or otherwise, since the 2015 quantitative goodwill test that would have had a significant negative impact on the valuation of the firm’s reporting units; As a result of the qualitative assessment, the firm determined that it was more likely than not that the fair value of each of the reporting units exceeded its respective carrying amount Notwithstanding the results of the qualitative assessment, since the 2015 quantitative goodwill test determined that the estimated fair value of the Fixed Income, Currency and Commodities Client Execution reporting unit was not substantially in excess of its carrying value, the firm also performed a quantitative test on this reporting unit during the fourth quarter of 2016 In the quantitative test, the estimated fair value of the Fixed Income, Currency and Commodities Client Execution reporting unit substantially exceeded its carrying value

#//In the context of Equity Method Investments, the investments accounted for under the equity method consist primarily of a 45% interest in Atlantic Methanol Production Company, LLC (AMPCO), which owns and operates a methanol plant and related facilities in Equatorial Guinea; a 28% interest in Alba Plant LLC (Alba Plant), which owns and operates a liquefied petroleum gas processing plant in Equatorial Guinea; and a 50% interest in CONE Gathering LLC (CONE), which owns and operates natural gas gathering facilities servicing our joint venture properties in the Marcellus Shale Equity method investments are included in other noncurrent assets in the consolidated balance sheets, and our share of earnings is reported as income from equity method investees in the consolidated statements of operations Our share of income taxes incurred directly by the equity method investees is reported in income from equity method investees and is not included in our income tax provision in our consolidated statements of operations; Additionally, the carrying values of equity method investments increased due to additional funding provided and interest earnings recorded on the note receivable from OWN, along with a $273 million step-up for the disposition of the Discovery Health network and retained equity interest in OWN, as noted in Note 4 However, these increases were partially offset by losses and dividends from equity method investments; The effective portion of the gains, before taxes, recognized on these cash flow hedges amounted to $14 million for 2013 The gain or loss related to hedge ineffectiveness was not material for 2013 There were no gains or losses excluded from the assessment of hedge effectiveness or reclassified to earnings from accumulated other comprehensive income during 2013; PMI has entered into foreign exchange contracts to hedge foreign currency exchange risk related to certain forecasted transactions The effective portion of gains and losses associated with qualifying cash flow hedge contracts is deferred as a component of accumulated other comprehensive losses until the underlying hedged transactions are reported in PMI’s consolidated statements of earnings During the years ended December 31, 2015, 2014, and 2013, ineffectiveness related to cash flow hedges was not material; The amounts recorded in “Cash flow hedges” will be reclassified to “Other principal transactions” in the same periods as the corresponding gain or loss on the sale of the hedged energy commodities, which is also recorded in “Other principal transactions ” The firm anticipates reclassifying $5 million of gains, net of taxes, related to cash flow hedges from “Cash flow hedges” to earnings within the next twelve months The duration over which the firm is hedging its exposure to the variability in future cash flows for forecasted transactions is approximately two years; #Conversely, personal injury costs, including asbestos-related claims, were $8 million lower in 2008 compared to 2007 This reduction reflects improvements in our safety experience and lower estimated costs to resolve claims, as indicated in the actuarial studies of our personal injury expense and annual reviews of asbestos-related claims in both 2008 and 2007 The year-over-year comparison also includes the negative impact of adverse development associated with one claim in 2008; Overall, the total change in other expenses amounts to $851 million, which is 100% of the total change; Specifically, Taiwan experienced an increase in other expenses due to higher amortization of DAC, a loss recognition adjustment, refinements from a new valuation system, and a restructuring charge Mexico's other expenses rose due to increased commissions aligned with revenue growth, higher DAC amortization, expenses related to growth initiatives, and additional costs from the Mexican pension business, although this was partially offset by the elimination of contingent liabilities from the previous year South Korea saw an increase in other expenses due to higher DAC amortization and general expenses, despite a decrease in DAC amortization from a refined reserve valuation system; Brazil's other expenses increased due to higher litigation liabilities Additionally, the home office incurred higher expenses from information technology projects, growth initiatives, integration costs, and increased compensation expenses, along with start-up costs for operations in Ireland In the Corporate & Other segment, the $287 million change accounts for 34% of the total change in other expenses; #//In the context of our assessment of impairment, we recorded a gross other-than-temporary impairment of $1 15 billion for the year 2009, which is a significant increase compared to the $122 million recorded for the year 2008 Of the total impairment recorded, $227 million was related to credit and was recognized in our consolidated statement of income; //In 2013, under the category of Other Operating Charges, the Company incurred a total of $895 million, which primarily included $494 million related to the Company’s Productivity and Reinvestment Program Additionally, there was $195 million attributed to the impairment of certain intangible assets, $188 million associated with the Company’s other productivity, integration, and restructuring initiatives, and $22 million due to charges related to certain of the Company’s fixed assets For further details on the impairment charges, please refer to Note 17 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements; The remaining $928 million was attributed to factors other than credit, which is discussed in more detail below, and was recognized, net of related taxes, in Other Comprehensive Income (OCI) in our consolidated statement of condition The $227 million related to credit was composed of $151 million associated with expected credit losses, $54 million related to management's decision to sell the impaired securities prior to their recovery in value, and $22 million related to adverse changes in the timing of expected future cash flows from the securities The majority of the impairment losses were related to non-agency securities that were collateralized by mortgages, for which management concluded that credit losses had occurred based on the present value of the securities' expected future cash flows; These securities are classified as asset-backed securities in the investment securities tables mentioned earlier As described in note 1, management periodically reviews the fair values of investment securities to determine if other-than-temporary impairment has occurred This review encompasses all investment securities and includes quantitative factors such as current and expected future interest rates, the length of time that a security's cost basis has exceeded its fair value, and investment securities for which we have issuer-specific concerns, regardless of quantitative factors; For more information regarding the Company’s Productivity and Reinvestment Program, as well as the other productivity, integration, and restructuring initiatives, please see Note 18 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements Lastly, for insights into the impact these charges had on our operating segments, refer to Note 19 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements; #//In the context of Equity Method Investments, the investments accounted for under the equity method consist primarily of a 45% interest in Atlantic Methanol Production Company, LLC (AMPCO), which owns and operates a methanol plant and related facilities in Equatorial Guinea; a 28% interest in Alba Plant LLC (Alba Plant), which owns and operates a liquefied petroleum gas processing plant in Equatorial Guinea; and a 50% interest in CONE Gathering LLC (CONE), which owns and operates natural gas gathering facilities servicing our joint venture properties in the Marcellus Shale Equity method investments are included in other noncurrent assets in the consolidated balance sheets, and our share of earnings is reported as income from equity method investees in the consolidated statements of operations Our share of income taxes incurred directly by the equity method investees is reported in income from equity method investees and is not included in our income tax provision in our consolidated statements of operations; Additionally, the carrying values of equity method investments increased due to additional funding provided and interest earnings recorded on the note receivable from OWN, along with a $273 million step-up for the disposition of the Discovery Health network and retained equity interest in OWN, as noted in Note 4 However, these increases were partially offset by losses and dividends from equity method investments; #The expected return on plan assets for the Defined Benefit Pension Plan was a negative $21 4 million in 2009 and a negative $1 7 million in 2008; For defined benefit pension plans, unrecognized gains and losses are amortized when they exceed 10% of the greater of the market-related value of plan assets or the projected benefit obligation at the beginning of the year For other postretirement benefits, amortization occurs when the net gains and losses exceed 10% of the accumulated postretirement benefit obligation at the beginning of the year The amount exceeding the corridor is amortized over the average remaining service period to retirement date for active plan participants or, for retired participants, the average remaining life expectancy; //The components of the net periodic benefit cost for the Defined Benefit Pension Plan in 2009 amounted to $0 2 million, while there was no cost recorded for 2008 The Postretirement Healthcare Plans had no service cost in both 2009 and 2008; The Supplemental Executive Retirement Plan had an interest cost of $0 5 million in 2009 and $0 1 million in 2008; The "Interest cost" row shows that for pension benefits, the interest cost for the year ended December 31, 2009, was $193 million, slightly lower than $195 million in 2008, and higher than $187 million in 2007 For postretirement benefits, the interest cost remained steady at $17 million for both 2009 and 2008, but decreased from $19 million in 2007 In the "Expected return on plan assets" row, the pension benefits for the year ended December 31, 2009, reflected a negative return of $207 million, which was also negative at $218 million in 2008 and $216 million in 2007; The Supplemental Executive Retirement Plan reported a net periodic benefit cost of $2 5 million in 2009 and $0 2 million in 2008

00 Bcf/d, and spans from Arkansas to Mississippi, connecting to NGPL, Trunkline Gas Company, Texas Gas Transmission, and ANR Pipeline Company KMLP has an ownership interest of 100%, operates 135 miles of pipeline, has a design capacity of 2 20 Bcf/d, and sources gas from the Cheniere Sabine Pass LNG terminal, interconnecting with Columbia Gulf, ANR, and various other pipelines; #//In the financial overview of operations, the total net revenue for fiscal 2012 was $4,151 million, which represents a 10% increase compared to the total net revenue of $3,772 million in fiscal 2011 The operating income from continuing operations for fiscal 2012 was $1,177 million, reflecting a 14% increase from the operating income of $1,037 million in fiscal 2011 The net income from continuing operations for fiscal 2012 was $767 million, marking an 18% increase from the net income of $652 million in fiscal 2011; When comparing fiscal 2012 to fiscal 2011, total net revenue increased by $379 million or 10%, driven by revenue growth in the Small Business Group and the Consumer Tax segment In the Small Business Group, revenue was up 14% The Financial Management Solutions segment saw an 11% increase in revenue due to growth in QuickBooks Online and QuickBooks Enterprise Solutions, along with higher financial supplies revenue; Revenues increased over each of the last two years primarily reflecting market growth in our Distribution Solutions segment, which accounted for approximately 97% of our consolidated revenues; There was no diluted earnings per share from discontinued operations in 2012, while in 2011, it was $0 28 The total diluted earnings per common share in 2012 was $5; 9% increase from $1,864 million in 2010 The income tax expense for 2012 was -$516 million, which is a 2% increase from -$505 million in 2011 and a decrease of 14 1% from -$601 million in 2010; Operating income from continuing operations increased by 14% in fiscal 2012 compared to fiscal 2011, attributed to the revenue increase, although this was partially offset by higher costs and operating expenses Excluding the $30 million fiscal 2011 goodwill and intangible asset impairment charge, total operating expenses were $159 million higher in fiscal 2012, which included approximately $144 million for higher staffing expenses and about $16 million for increased share-based compensation expenses Net income from continuing operations increased by 18% in fiscal 2012 compared to fiscal 2011, driven by the increase in operating income, lower interest expense due to debt repayment during the year, and a slightly lower effective tax rate

#//In the context of Interest Rate Derivatives, the company entered into three interest rate swap contracts, designated as cash flow hedges, in connection with the issuance of floating rate debt in August and October 2008, to hedge against changes in interest payments due to fluctuations in the underlying benchmark rate In December 2010, the company approved a plan to refinance the term loan in January 2011, which resulted in an $8 6 million loss on derivative instruments due to ineffectiveness on the associated interest rate swap contract; To mitigate counterparty credit risk, the interest rate swap contracts required collateralization by both counterparties for the swaps’ aggregate net fair value during their respective terms, with collateral maintained in the form of cash and adjusted on a daily basis In February 2010, the company entered into a forward starting interest rate swap contract, designated as a cash flow hedge, to hedge against changes in interest payments due to fluctuations in the underlying benchmark rate between the date of the swap and the forecasted issuance of fixed rate debt in March 2010, and the swap was highly effective; As of December 31, 2007, based on the company’s stock price, the redemption value of this embedded derivative was approximately $87 million; The effectiveness of these hedges is evaluated using either the perfectly effective hypothetical derivative method or by assessing changes in the present value of interest payments on the underlying debt Effective gains and losses that are deferred to Accumulated Other Comprehensive Income (AOCI) are reclassified into earnings over the life of the associated debt, while ineffective gains and losses are recorded as net interest The amount of hedge ineffectiveness was reported as less than $1 million in fiscal 2019, a loss of $2; Treasury rates, LIBOR, Euribor, and commercial paper rates in both the United States and Europe To manage our exposure to interest rate changes and reduce the volatility of our financing costs, we utilize interest rate swaps, forward-starting interest rate swaps, and treasury locks, aiming to achieve a desired balance of fixed-rate versus floating-rate debt based on current and projected market conditions In the context of floating interest rate exposures, floating-to-fixed interest rate swaps are treated as cash flow hedges, which also applies to all hedges of forecasted debt issuances; //The interest rate risk exposure indicates that we are affected by interest rate volatility concerning future issuances of fixed-rate debt, as well as existing and future issuances of floating-rate debt The primary exposures include U S
#//In 2016, Comcast Corporation reported an estimated amortization expense of finite-lived intangible assets amounting to $1,785 In 2017, the estimated amortization expense decreased to $1,612 The following year, 2018, the estimated amortization expense further declined to $1,365; //The row header is "Goodwill" and the column header is "Intangibles," which indicates that the cell states that the company consists of customer-related intangibles of approximately $36 5 million and network location intangibles of approximately $27 0 million; In 2019, the estimated amortization expense was $1,039, and by 2020, it reached $902 Finite-lived intangible assets are subject to amortization and primarily consist of customer relationships acquired in business combinations, software, cable franchise renewal costs, contractual operating rights, and intellectual property rights These assets are amortized primarily on a straight-line basis over their estimated useful life or the term of the associated agreement; This evaluation is based on the cash flows generated by the underlying asset groups, which includes estimated future operating results, trends, or other determinants of fair value If the total of the expected future undiscounted cash flows is less than the carrying amount of the asset group, an impairment charge is recognized to the extent that the carrying amount of the asset group exceeds its estimated fair value Unless presented separately, this impairment charge is included as a component of amortization expense; Maintenance and training costs, along with costs incurred during the preliminary stage of a project, are expensed as they are incurred Initial operating system software costs are capitalized and amortized over the life of the associated hardware The company evaluates the recoverability of its finite-lived intangible assets whenever events or substantive changes in circumstances suggest that the carrying amount may not be recoverable; The customer-related intangibles and network location intangibles are being amortized on a straight-line basis over periods of up to 20 years The row header is "Goodwill" and the column header is "Tax Deductibility," which indicates that the company expects that the goodwill recorded will not be deductible for tax purposes The goodwill was allocated to the company’s international rental and management segment

#dollar forward contracts are designated and qualify for hedge accounting as of each period presented below The currencies in this table represent 98 percent and 97 percent of the notional amounts of contracts outstanding as of December 31, 2011, and 2010, as noted in the Foreign Exchange Rates section; The currencies listed in this table represent 94 percent and 95 percent of the notional amounts of contracts outstanding as of December 31, 2013, and 2012, respectively; //The table summarizes our outstanding foreign currency forward contracts, which are considered economic hedges to minimize income volatility resulting from the remeasurement of net monetary assets and payables denominated in a currency other than the functional currency The objective of these contracts is to offset the gain or loss from remeasurement with the gain or loss from the fair market valuation of the forward contract It is important to note that these derivative instruments are not designated as hedges under GAAP; These foreign currency forward contracts are designated and qualify as foreign currency cash flow hedges under GAAP The effective portion of the unrealized gain or loss on the forward contract is deferred and reported as a component of “Accumulated other comprehensive loss” (AOCL) When the hedged forecasted transaction (sale or purchase) occurs, the unrealized gain or loss is reclassified into income in the same line item associated with the hedged transaction in the same period or periods during which the hedged transaction affects income; The ineffective portion of the hedge, unrealized gain or loss, if any, is recognized in current income during the period of change, as described in the Foreign Exchange Rates section As of December 31, 2011, the amount we expect to reclassify from AOCL to income over the next year is an unrealized net loss of $6 million, as noted in the Foreign Exchange Rates section For the years ended December 31, 2011, and 2010, there were no circumstances that would have resulted in the discontinuance of a foreign currency cash flow hedge, as mentioned in the Foreign Exchange Rates section; We transact business in foreign currencies, and as a result, our income experiences some volatility related to movements in foreign currency exchange rates To help manage our exposure to exchange rate volatility, we use foreign exchange forward contracts on a regular basis to hedge forecasted intercompany and third-party sales and purchases denominated in non-functional currencies Our internal policy allows for managing anticipated foreign currency cash flows for up to one year, as stated in the Foreign Exchange Rates section

#By the end of 2017, the goodwill balance increased to $13,220 million, compared to $13,118 million at the end of 2016; //In 2017, the beginning of the year balance for goodwill was $13,118 million, while in 2016, it was $13,123 million During 2017, there was an acquisition that contributed $121 million to goodwill, which included $91 million related to the First Reserve Transaction, enhancing the Company’s energy and power infrastructure platform, and $30 million related to the Cachematrix Transaction, which improved the Company’s technology and cash management capabilities Additionally, there were goodwill adjustments related to Quellos amounting to -$19 million in both 2017 and 2016; //In the context of GOODWILL, we evaluate goodwill for potential impairment annually and at an interim date if indicators of impairment exist When using the quantitative process to evaluate goodwill for potential impairment, consistent with our early adoption of ASU No 2017-04 in January 2017, we compare the estimated fair value of the reporting unit to the carrying value; Changes in the estimates and assumptions used in our goodwill impairment testing could result in future impairment losses, which could be material Additionally, when a portion of a reporting unit is disposed, goodwill is allocated to the gain or loss on disposition based on the relative fair values of the business or businesses disposed and the portion of the reporting unit that will be retained When determining the fair value of the businesses disposed of and the reporting unit to be retained, we use estimates and assumptions similar to those used in our impairment analysis; The weighted average cost of capital is estimated based on each reporting unit’s cost of debt and equity and a selected capital structure The selected capital structure for each reporting unit is based on consideration of capital structures of comparable publicly traded companies operating in the business of that reporting unit We had $5,190 million of goodwill as of December 31, 2017; When determining the estimated fair value, we utilize discounted future cash flow models, as well as market conditions relative to the operations of our reporting units Under the discounted cash flow approach, we utilize various assumptions that require judgment, including projections of revenues and expenses based on estimated long-term growth rates, and discount rates based on weighted average cost of capital Our estimates of long-term growth and costs are based on historical data, as well as various internal projections and external sources

#In 2012, compared to 2011, MST's operating profit increased by $92 million, or 14% This increase was primarily due to a higher operating profit of approximately $175 million from ship and aviation system programs, reflecting higher volume and risk retirements on certain programs, particularly VLS, PTDS, MH-60, and LCS There were also reserves of about $55 million for contract cost matters on ship and aviation system programs recorded in the fourth quarter of 2011, including the terminated presidential helicopter program; However, this increase was partially offset by lower operating profit of approximately $40 million from undersea systems programs due to reduced profit booking rates and lower volume on an international combat system program and towed array systems, as well as about $40 million from lower volume on various other programs Adjustments not related to volume, including net profit booking rate adjustments and other matters, were approximately $150 million higher for 2012 compared to 2011; //In 2011, compared to 2010, MST’s net sales decreased by $311 million, or 4% This decrease was primarily due to a reduced volume of approximately $390 million for certain ship and aviation system programs, particularly the Maritime Patrol Aircraft and PTDS, along with a decrease of about $75 million for training and logistics solutions programs However, these decreases were partially offset by an increase in sales of approximately $165 million from production on the LCS program; //In 2011, compared to 2010, MFC's net sales increased by $533 million, or 8% This increase was primarily due to a higher volume of about $420 million from air and missile defense programs, mainly PAC-3 and THAAD, and about $245 million from fire control systems programs, particularly related to the SOF CLSS program that began late in the third quarter of 2010 However, these increases were partially offset by lower net sales resulting from a decreased volume of approximately $75 million from various services programs and about $20 million from tactical missile programs, primarily MLRS and JASSM; In 2011, MST’s operating profit decreased by $68 million, or 10%, compared to 2010 This decline was attributed to a decrease in operating profit of approximately $55 million due to increased reserves for contract cost matters on various ship and aviation system programs, including the terminated presidential helicopter program, and about $40 million due to lower volume and increased reserves on training and logistics solutions Nonetheless, these decreases were partially offset by a higher operating profit of approximately $30 million in 2011, primarily resulting from the recognition of reserves on certain undersea systems programs in 2010; In the Mission Systems and Training segment, our MST business provides various systems including surface ship and submarine combat systems, missile defense systems, radar systems, mission systems and sensors for aircraft, littoral combat ships, simulation and training services, unmanned technologies, ship systems integration, and military and commercial training systems Major programs in MST include Aegis, MK-41 Vertical Launching System (VLS), TPQ-53 Radar System, MH-60, LCS, and PTDS In 2012, compared to 2011, MST's net sales increased by $447 million, or 6%

//In 2010, the integration initiative for the integration of CCE’s North American business began after the acquisition of CCE’s North American business, aiming to develop, design, and implement a future operating framework Upon completion of the CCE transaction, the management of the acquired North American business was combined with the management of the existing foodservice business, Minute Maid and Odwalla juice businesses, North America supply chain operations, and Company-owned bottling operations in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, into a unified organization called Coca-Cola Refreshments, or CCR Additionally, the remaining CCNA operations were reshaped into an organization that primarily provides franchise leadership and consumer marketing and innovation for the North American market

Premium deficiency reserves have been recorded for the group single premium annuity business, which includes limited-payment, long-duration traditional and non-participating annuities, structured settlements, and single premium immediate annuities with life contingencies, as well as for certain individual health policies The liabilities of $2,658 million and $3,034 million are included in “Future policy benefits” for these deficiencies at December 31, 2006, and 2005, respectively Additionally, the Company’s liability for future policy benefits includes liabilities for guarantee benefits related to certain nontraditional long-duration life and annuity contracts, which are discussed in more detail in Note 9; 5% to 8%, and less than 1% of the reserves are based on an interest rate exceeding 8% Participating insurance accounted for 23% of domestic individual life insurance in force at December 31, 2005, down from 26% in 2004, and represented 90%, 91%, and 92% of domestic individual life insurance premiums for the years 2005, 2004, and 2003, respectively For individual non-participating traditional life insurance policies, group and individual long-term care policies, and individual health insurance policies, future policy benefits are determined by the present value of future benefit payments and related expenses, minus the present value of future net premiums, along with any premium deficiency reserves; Additionally, the operating profits in 2014 included $8 million of costs associated with sheet plant closures, while the operating profits in 2013 included costs of $45 million related to the permanent shutdown of a paper machine at our Augusta, Georgia mill and $2 million of costs associated with the sale of the Shorewood business

5 billion stock repurchase program approved by the Board of Directors in March 2011, known as the “2011 Buyback ” Under this program, management is authorized to purchase shares from time to time through open market purchases or privately negotiated transactions at prevailing prices, as permitted by securities laws and other legal requirements, and subject to market conditions and other factors To facilitate these repurchases, the issuer makes purchases pursuant to trading plans under Rule 10b5-1 of the Exchange Act, which allows for repurchasing shares during periods when the issuer might otherwise be prevented from doing so under insider trading laws or due to self-imposed trading blackout periods; #Table 36 presents nonperforming consumer loans and foreclosed properties activity during 2011 and 2010 Nonperforming loans do not include past due consumer credit card loans and generally exclude past due consumer loans not secured by real estate, as these loans are typically charged off no later than the end of the month in which they become 180 days past due The fully insured loan portfolio is not reported as nonperforming since principal repayment is insured; In the Commercial nonperforming loans category, the U S commercial loans were $2,174 million in 2011, down from $3,453 million in 2010, $4,925 million in 2009, $2,040 million in 2008, and $852 million in 2007; S commercial loans stood at $143 million in 2011, down from $233 million in 2010, $177 million in 2009, $290 million in 2008, and $19 million in 2007 The total commercial nonperforming loans were $6,223 million in 2011, compared to $9,632 million in 2010, $12,503 million in 2009, $6,292 million in 2008, and $2,003 million in 2007; The total nonperforming loans, leases, and foreclosed properties reached $27,708 million in 2011, down from $32,664 million in 2010, $35,747 million in 2009, $18,212 million in 2008, and $5,948 million in 2007; Net changes to foreclosed properties related to PCI loans increased by $411 million in 2011 Not included in foreclosed properties at December 31, 2011, was $1 4 billion of real estate acquired upon foreclosure of delinquent FHA-insured loans, which is held on the balance sheet until conveyed to the FHA; The U S small business commercial loans were $114 million in 2011, down from $204 million in 2010, $200 million in 2009, $205 million in 2008, and $152 million in 2007

#//In Note 9 of the Consolidated Financial Statements, it is explained that collateralized agreements and financings involve securities purchased under agreements to resell and securities borrowed, as well as securities sold under agreements to repurchase and securities loaned The firm engages in these transactions to facilitate client activities, invest excess cash, acquire securities to cover short positions, and finance certain firm activities It is noted that collateralized agreements and financings are presented on a net-by-counterparty basis when a legal right of setoff exists; For resale agreements, the firm typically requires collateral with a fair value approximately equal to the carrying value of the relevant assets Although these agreements involve a legal transfer of ownership, they are accounted for as financing arrangements due to the obligation to repurchase or resell the instruments However, "repos to maturity" are treated as sales, and as of December 2012 or December 2011, the firm had no repos to maturity outstanding; 40 billion and $47 62 billion of securities borrowed, and $1 56 billion and $107 million of securities loaned were at fair value, respectively; Interest on these agreements is recognized over the life of the transaction and is included in "Interest income" and "Interest expense " For further details about interest income and interest expense, one should refer to Note 23 The table presents the carrying value of resale and repurchase agreements and securities borrowed and loaned transactions as of December; In millions, the carrying value of securities purchased under agreements to resell was $141,334 in 2012 and $187,789 in 2011 The carrying value of securities borrowed was $136,893 in 2012 and $153,341 in 2011 The carrying value of securities sold under agreements to repurchase was $171,807 in 2012 and $164,502 in 2011; #These affiliated company transactions include affiliated company power sales agreements between FirstEnergy's competitive and regulated companies, support service billings, interest on affiliated company notes including the money pools, and other transactions FirstEnergy's competitive companies provide power through affiliated company power sales to meet a portion of the Ohio and Pennsylvania Companies' POLR and default service requirements Prior to 2011, Met-Ed and Penelec had a partial requirement PSA with FES to meet a portion of their POLR obligations; Support services expenses totaled $584 million for FES, $141 million for OE, $62 million for CEI, $59 million for TE, $91 million for JCP&L, $54 million for Met-Ed, and $57 million for Penelec Regarding investment income for 2009, interest income from affiliates was not reported for FES, while it was $15 million for OE, $17 million for TE, and no income was reported for CEI, JCP&L, Met-Ed, or Penelec Interest income from FE was $4 million for FES, $1 million for OE, and $1 million for Met-Ed, with no income reported for CEI, TE, JCP&L, or Penelec; In 2011, interest expenses to FE amounted to $1 million for FES, while OE had no interest expenses to FE, and CEI, TE, JCP&L, Met-Ed, and Penelec each had $1 million in interest expenses to FE Prior to the change in composition of business segments, FirstEnergy's business was comprised of two reportable operating segments The Energy Delivery Services segment was comprised of FirstEnergy's then eight existing utility operating companies that transmit and distribute electricity to customers and purchase power to serve their POLR and default service requirements; The Competitive Energy Services segment was comprised of FES, which supplies electric power to end-use customers through retail and wholesale arrangements The "Other/Corporate" amounts consisted of corporate items and other businesses that were below the quantifiable threshold for separate disclosure Disclosures for FirstEnergy's operating segments for 2010 have been reclassified to conform to the revised presentation; The changes in FirstEnergy's reportable segments during 2011 consisted primarily of the following:   Energy Delivery Services was renamed Regulated Distribution, and the operations of MP, PE, and WP, which were acquired as part of the merger with AE, and certain regulatory asset recovery mechanisms formerly included in the "Other/Corporate" segment, were placed into this segment A new Regulated Independent Transmission segment was created consisting of ATSI, and the operations of TrAIL and FirstEnergy's interest in PATH; TrAIL and PATH were acquired as part of the merger with AE The transmission assets and operations of JCP&L, Met-Ed, Penelec, MP, PE, and WP remained within the Regulated Distribution segment; Interest expense to FE was not reported for FES, OE, or TE, while it was $1 million for CEI, and no expenses were reported for JCP&L, Met-Ed, or Penelec In the section for the year 2009, the revenues from electric sales to affiliates totaled $2,826 million for FES, $189 million for OE, $2 million for CEI, $38 million for TE, and no revenue for JCP&L, Met-Ed, or Penelec The ground lease with ATSI generated $12 million for OE, $7 million for CEI, and $2 million for TE, with no revenue reported for FES, JCP&L, Met-Ed, or Penelec

#In millions of dollars, the amount of gain (loss) recognized in AOCI on derivative interest rate contracts for the year 2018 was $-361, for 2017 it was $-165, and for 2016 it was $-219 For foreign exchange contracts, the amounts were 5 for 2018, -8 for 2017, and 69 for 2016 The total gain (loss) recognized in AOCI for 2018 was $-356, for 2017 it was $-173, and for 2016 it was $-150; Regarding the amount of gain (loss) reclassified from AOCI to earnings, for interest rate contracts in Other revenue for the year 2018, the amount was $—, for 2017 it was $-126, and for 2016 it was $-140 For foreign exchange contracts, the amounts were -17 for 2018, — for 2017, and -10 for 2016 The total gain (loss) reclassified from AOCI into earnings for 2018 was $-17, for 2017 it was $-301, and for 2016 it was $-136, with a total of $-233 for 2016; Before this adoption, to the extent that these derivatives were not fully effective, changes in their fair values that exceeded changes in the value of the hedged transactions were immediately included in Other revenue Following the adoption of ASU 2017-12, such amounts are no longer required to be immediately recognized in income; instead, the full change in the value of the hedging instrument must be recognized in AOCI and then recognized in earnings in the same period that the cash flows impact earnings The pretax change in AOCI from cash flow hedges is presented below for the year ended December 31; After January 1, 2018, all amounts reclassified into earnings for interest rate contracts are included in Interest income/Interest expense (Net interest revenue) For all other hedges, including interest rate hedges prior to January 1, 2018, the amounts reclassified to earnings are primarily included in Other revenue and Net interest revenue in the Consolidated Statement of Income For cash flow hedges, the changes in the fair value of the hedging derivative remain in AOCI on the Consolidated Balance Sheet and will be included in the earnings of future periods to offset the variability of the hedged cash flows when such cash flows affect earnings; //In the context of Cash Flow Hedges, Citigroup hedges the variability of forecasted cash flows associated with floating-rate assets/liabilities and other forecasted transactions The variable cash flows from those liabilities are synthetically converted to fixed-rate cash flows by entering into receive-variable, pay-fixed interest rate swaps and receive-variable, pay-fixed forward-starting interest rate swaps Additionally, variable cash flows associated with certain assets are synthetically converted to fixed-rate cash flows by entering into receive-fixed, pay-variable interest rate swaps; These cash flow hedging relationships utilize either regression analysis or dollar-offset ratio analysis to evaluate whether the hedging relationships are highly effective at inception and on an ongoing basis Prior to the adoption of ASU 2017-12, Citigroup designated the risk being hedged as the risk of overall variability in the hedged cash flows for certain items However, with the adoption of ASU 2017-12, Citigroup now hedges the variability from changes in a contractually specified rate and recognizes the entire change in fair value of the cash flow hedging instruments in Accumulated Other Comprehensive Income (AOCI)

#//The unsecured term loan credit facility, known as the 2015 Term Loan, was entered into in April 2015 and had $600 million outstanding as of December 31, 2016, while it had $750 million outstanding as of December 31, 2015 Our revolving credit facility and term loan facilities require us to maintain certain financial covenants, as outlined in Note F—Borrowings and Credit Arrangements to our consolidated financial statements contained in Item 8 of this Annual Report As of and through December 31, 2016, we were in compliance with the required covenants; Any inability to maintain compliance with these covenants could require us to seek to renegotiate the terms of our credit facility or seek waivers from compliance with these covenants, both of which could result in additional borrowing costs Furthermore, there can be no assurance that our lenders would agree to such new terms or grant such waivers Regarding our Senior Notes, we had senior notes outstanding of $4; //Liquidity and Capital Resources Overview states that during the year ended December 31, 2016, we increased our financial flexibility and our ability to grow our business while maintaining our long-term financial policies Our significant 2016 financing transactions included registered public offerings of $750 0 million aggregate principal amount of 3; 300% senior unsecured notes due 2021 (the “3 300% Notes”) and $500 0 million aggregate principal amount of 4; 125% Notes”) Furthermore, we amended our multicurrency senior unsecured revolving credit facility entered into in June 2013, as amended (the “2013 Credit Facility”), our senior unsecured revolving credit facility entered into in January 2012, as amended and restated in September 2014, as further amended (the “2014 Credit Facility”), and our unsecured term loan entered into in October 2013, as amended (the “Term Loan”) to, among other things, extend the maturity dates by one year As a holding company, our cash flows are derived primarily from the operations of, and distributions from, our operating subsidiaries or funds raised through borrowings under our credit facilities and debt or equity offerings; Under these interest rate swaps, the Company exchanges the difference between fixed and floating interest rates at specified intervals, based on an agreed notional principal amount, without any cash exchanged at the contract's outset Exchange-traded futures and options are also used to mitigate market risks from interest rate changes and to address duration mismatches between assets and liabilities The Company enters into these transactions with regulated futures commissions merchants and posts variation margin daily based on market value changes

For these public fixed maturity securities, the fair value is based on non-binding broker quotes, if available, or determined using a discounted cash flow model or internally developed values For private fixed maturities, fair value is determined using a discounted cash flow model, which utilizes a discount rate based on the average of spread surveys collected from private market intermediaries active in both primary and secondary transactions, considering factors such as credit quality and industry sector of the issuer and the reduced liquidity associated with private placements In determining the fair value of certain fixed maturity securities, the discounted cash flow model may also use unobservable inputs reflecting the Company’s own assumptions about the inputs market participants would use in pricing the security; For Policy loans, the fair value at Level 1 is $0, at Level 2 is $0, at Level 3 is $11,657, totaling $11,657, and the carrying amount is also $11,657 In the category of Other long-term investments, the fair value at Level 1 is $0, at Level 2 is $0, at Level 3 is $1,653, totaling $1,653, with a carrying amount of $1,563 For Short-term investments, the fair value at Level 1 is $0, at Level 2 is $617, at Level 3 is $1, totaling $618, and the carrying amount is $618; #//In 2010, the total sales from oil amounted to $2,169 million, while bitumen sales were $474 million, gas sales reached $3,572 million, NGLs sales were $1,047 million, leading to a total of $7,262 million The change in sales due to volumes in 2010 showed an increase of $30 million for oil, $193 million for bitumen, $88 million for gas, and $147 million for NGLs, resulting in a total volume change of $458 million The change in sales due to prices in 2010 indicated an increase of $461 million for oil, $72 million for bitumen, a decrease of $249 million for gas, and an increase of $311 million for NGLs, culminating in a total price change of $595 million; Specifically, oil sales increased by $337 million due to the continued development of liquids-rich properties in the Permian Basin, while bitumen sales rose by $273 million due to the development of Jackfish thermal heavy oil projects in Canada Additionally, NGL sales increased by $137 million as a result of ongoing drilling in the liquids-rich gas areas of the Barnett Shale, Cana-Woodford Shale, and Granite Wash However, these increases were partially offset by a slight decrease in gas production in 2012, resulting in a $52 million decline in gas sales; In 2011, oil sales rose to $2,660 million, bitumen sales increased to $739 million, gas sales decreased to $3,411 million, NGLs sales grew to $1,505 million, resulting in a total of $8,315 million The change in sales due to volumes in 2011 reflected an increase of $337 million for oil, $273 million for bitumen, a decrease of $52 million for gas, and an increase of $137 million for NGLs, leading to a total volume change of $695 million Conversely, the change in sales due to prices in 2011 showed a decrease of $101 million for oil, a decrease of $181 million for bitumen, a significant decrease of $1,148 million for gas, and a decrease of $427 million for NGLs, resulting in a total price change of -$1,857 million; In 2012, oil sales reached $2,896 million, bitumen sales were $831 million, gas sales dropped to $2,211 million, NGLs sales increased to $1,215 million, leading to a total of $7,153 million The volumes in 2012 compared to 2011 indicated that upstream sales increased by $695 million due to a 4 percent increase in production The increase in oil and bitumen production were the largest contributors to this rise, accounting for nearly 90 percent of the higher sales; #S softwood and hardwood pulp prices improved during the first and second quarters of 2005, then declined in the third quarter, but showed some recovery toward the end of the year Softwood pulp prices finished the year about 2% lower than in 2004 but were 15% higher than in 2003, while hardwood pulp prices ended the year approximately 15% higher than in 2004 and 10% higher than in 2003; //In the context of the financial performance of the company, the higher raw material and energy costs of $312 million, increased market-related downtime of $187 million, and other items totaling $30 million were more than offset by the overall earnings When comparing the years 2003 and 2005, it was noted that the higher earnings in the Brazilian Papers, U S; S uncoated papers and the European Papers businesses In the Printing Papers segment, there was a total of 995,000 tons of downtime in 2005, which included 540,000 tons attributed to lack-of-order downtime to better align production with customer demand; 2% lower than in 2003 To align productive capacity with customer demand, the business announced the permanent closure of three uncoated freesheet machines and experienced significant downtime due to lack of orders during the period Towards the end of the year, demand showed some improvement, aided by the introduction of a new line of vision innovation paper products (VIP TechnologiesTM), which featured enhanced brightness and whiteness; The business reported an operating profit in 2005, contrasting with a small operating loss in 2004 This earnings improvement was driven by higher average sales prices and enhanced mill operations, with price realizations in 2005 averaging 13% higher than in 2004 However, higher input costs for raw materials and energy partially offset the benefits from improved prices and operations, and sales volumes were approximately 1% lower in 2005 compared to 2004; Market Pulp sales from U S and European facilities totaled $757 million in 2005, compared to $661 million in 2004 and $571 million in 2003

#//The discount to Brent in the International E&P Liquid hydrocarbons category was narrower in 2013 than in 2012 and 2011 As a result of the significant increase in U S; The average Henry Hub settlement prices for natural gas were 31 percent higher in 2013 than in 2012 In the International E&P Liquid hydrocarbons category, our International E&P crude oil production is relatively sweet and has historically sold in relation to the Brent crude benchmark, which on average was 3 percent lower in 2013 than in 2012 In the Natural gas section, our major International E&P natural gas-producing regions are Europe and E; Regarding Natural gas, a significant portion of our natural gas production in the U S is sold at bid-week prices or first-of-month indices relative to our specific producing areas; production of light sweet crude oil, the historical relationship between WTI, Brent, and LLS pricing may not be indicative of future periods In the Composition section, the proportion of our liquid hydrocarbon sales volumes that are NGLs continues to increase due to our development of United States unconventional liquids-rich plays In 2013, NGLs accounted for 15 percent of our North America E&P liquid hydrocarbon sales volumes, compared to 10 percent in 2012 and 7 percent in 2011; #e , the year the loans were sold) based on a combination of historical trends and forecasted repurchases and losses considering the: (1) trends in requests by investors for loan documentation packages to be reviewed; (2) trends in recent repurchases and make-wholes; (3) historical percentage of claims made as a percentage of loan documentation package requests; (4) success rate in appealing claims; (5) inventory of unresolved claims; and (6) estimated loss given repurchase or make-whole, including the loss of principal, accrued interest, and foreclosure costs The Company does not change its estimation methodology by counterparty, but the historical experience and trends are considered when evaluating the overall reserve; 9 million as of December 31, 2009, in contrast to $4 6 million on December 31, 2008; //The Share Repurchase Plan states that on April 23, 2008, the board of directors authorized a new share repurchase program of up to $1 5 billion with no stated expiration date During the year ended December 31, 2009, there were no purchases under this program, while on December 31, 2008, 5; Payments to make the investor whole are also treated as utilizations and charged directly against the reserve The provision for estimated probable losses arising from loan sales is recorded as an adjustment to the gain on sale, which is included in Other revenue in the Consolidated Statement of Income A liability for representations and warranties is estimated when the Company sells loans and is updated quarterly; The request for loan documentation packages is an early indicator of a potential claim During 2009, loan documentation package requests and the level of outstanding claims increased In addition, our loss severity estimates increased during 2009 due to the impact of macroeconomic factors and recent experience; The total medical and other expenses payable as of December 31, 2004, was $1,422,010, which is 100 0% of the total Estimating IBNR is complex and involves a significant amount of judgment, and accordingly, it represents a critical accounting estimate; Gross unrealized losses and fair value aggregated by investment category and length of time that individual securities have been in a continuous unrealized loss position were as follows at December 31, 2005, and 2004; The completion factor is a calculation of the percentage of claims incurred during a given period that have historically been adjudicated as of the reporting period For the most recent three months, the incurred claims are estimated primarily from a trend analysis based upon per member per month claims trends developed from our historical experience in the preceding months, adjusted for known changes in estimates of recent hospital and drug utilization data, provider contracting changes, changes in benefit levels, product mix, and weekday seasonality, which are expected to be higher than the otherwise estimated value of such claims at the time of the estimate Therefore, in many situations, the claim amounts ultimately settled will be less than the estimate that satisfies the actuarial standards of practice; #, who accounts for 8 2% of our share of annualized cash rent, no other tenant in our portfolio accounted for more than 5 0% of our share of annualized cash rent, including our share of joint venture annualized cash rent, at December 31, 2018; In terms of earnings per unit of the Operating Partnership, we present both basic and diluted earnings per unit, or EPU, using the two-class method, which is an earnings allocation formula that determines EPU for common units and any participating securities according to dividends declared (whether paid or unpaid) Under the two-class method, basic EPU is computed by dividing the income available to common unitholders by the weighted-average number of common units outstanding for the period, including participating securities consisting of unvested restricted units that receive nonforfeitable dividends similar to shares of common units Diluted EPU reflects the potential dilution that could occur if securities or other contracts to issue common units were exercised or converted into common units, where such exercise or conversion would result in a lower EPU amount, and the dilutive effect of unit options is reflected in the weighted average diluted outstanding units calculation by application of the treasury stock method, with no dilutive effect for the exchangeable senior notes as the conversion premium was to be paid in cash; //In May 2017, the Company entered into an agreement with 50 HYMC Owner LLC for the lease of approximately 847,000 square feet of office space located at 50 Hudson Yards, New York, New York The term of the lease is twenty years from the date that rental payments begin, which is expected to occur in May 2023, with the option to renew for a specified term The lease requires annual base rental payments of approximately $51 million per year during the first five years of the lease term, which will increase every five years to $58 million, $66 million, and $74 million per year, totaling approximately $1; For the years ended December 31, 2018, 2017, and 2016, the following properties contributed more than 5 0% of our annualized cash rent, including our share of joint venture annualized cash rent; 6 million in dividends to our common stockholders on an annual basis Before we pay any dividend, we consider various pricing models, replacement costs, and termination costs to determine fair value In the normal course of business, we are exposed to the effect of interest rate changes and limit these risks by following established risk management policies and procedures, including the use of derivatives; The changes in fair value of hedge instruments are reflected in accumulated other comprehensive income For derivative instruments not designated as hedging instruments, the gain or loss resulting from the change in the estimated fair value of the derivative instruments is recognized in current earnings during the period of change In terms of earnings per share of the Company, we present both basic and diluted earnings per share, or EPS, using the two-class method, which is an earnings allocation formula that determines EPS for common stock and any participating securities according to dividends declared (whether paid or unpaid)

//In the category of Restricted Stock and Restricted Stock Units, it is stated that employees may be granted restricted (non-vested) stock and/or restricted stock units without cost to them The restricted stock and restricted stock units generally vest five years after the date of grant, except for certain bonus grants, and as defined in individual grant agreements Upon vesting of restricted stock, shares of Common Stock are released to the employee, and upon vesting, restricted stock units are converted into shares of Common Stock and released to the employee; #//In the section titled "Other commitments and contingencies," it is noted that, as described in note 20, in the normal course of business, various commitments and contingent liabilities are outstanding, such as loan commitments, credit guarantees, and letters of credit Under the header "Pricing of Financial Instruments," it is stated that the Company’s pricing of such financial instruments is based largely on credit quality and relationship, probability of funding, and other requirements In the context of "Loan Commitments," it is mentioned that loan commitments often have fixed expiration dates and contain termination and other clauses which provide for relief from funding in the event of significant deterioration in the credit quality of the customer; Regarding "Rates and Terms," it is indicated that the rates and terms of the Company’s loan commitments, credit guarantees, and letters of credit are competitive with other financial institutions operating in markets served by the Company In the section on "Carrying Amounts," it is asserted that the Company believes that the carrying amounts, which are included in other liabilities, are reasonable estimates of the fair value of these financial instruments Under "Earnings Power and Value," it is expressed that the Company does not believe that the estimated information presented herein is representative of the earnings power or value of the Company; //The section on Guarantees and Indemnifications states that FIN 45 requires a guarantor, upon issuance of a guarantee, to recognize a liability for the fair value of the obligation it undertakes in issuing the guarantee To measure the fair value of a guarantee liability, we recognize a liability for any premium received or receivable in exchange for the guarantee For a guarantee issued as part of a larger transaction, such as in association with an asset sale or executory contract, we recognize a liability for any premium that we would have received had we issued the guarantee as a single item; Finally, in the section on "Realized Amounts," it is stated that because the disclosed fair value amounts were estimated as of the balance sheet date, the amounts actually realized or paid upon maturity or settlement of the various financial instruments could be significantly different In the section titled "Commitments and Contingencies," it is reiterated that in the normal course of business, various commitments and contingent liabilities are outstanding Lastly, the table presents the Company’s significant commitments, noting that certain of these commitments are not included in the Company’s consolidated balance sheet; In the analysis of "Fair Value Limitations," it is noted that the preceding analysis, which is inherently limited in depicting fair value, also does not consider any value associated with existing customer relationships nor the ability of the Company to create value through loan origination, deposit gathering, or fee-generating activities In the context of "Subjective Estimates," it is highlighted that many of the estimates presented herein are based upon the use of highly subjective information and assumptions and, accordingly, the results may not be precise Regarding "Comparability of Fair Value Estimates," it is mentioned that management believes that fair value estimates may not be comparable between financial institutions due to the wide range of permitted valuation techniques and numerous estimates which must be made; In the Mutual Funds section, it is stated that mutual funds represent shares in registered investment companies that are priced based on the daily quoted NAVs that are publicly available and are the basis for transactions to buy or sell shares in the funds Lastly, the Pooled Funds section describes that pooled funds include both common and collective trust funds as well as special funds that contain only employee benefit plan assets from two or more unrelated benefit plans The investment components of these funds are presented in the following table

#At the end of the year 2015, the backlog for Aeronautics stood at $31,800 million, an increase from $27,600 million in 2014 and $28,000 million in 2013 When comparing 2015 to 2014, Aeronautics’ net sales increased by $650 million, or 4%, primarily due to higher net sales of approximately $1 4 billion for F-35 production contracts resulting from increased volume on aircraft production and sustainment activities, along with approximately $150 million for the C-5 program due to increased deliveries; These increases were partially offset by lower net sales for the F-35 development contract and the C-130 program In terms of operating profit, Aeronautics experienced an increase of $37 million, or 2%, in 2014 compared to 2013, primarily due to higher operating profit for the F-35 development contract, the F-22 program, and the C-130 program, although these were offset by lower operating profit for the F-16 program and sustainment activities Overall, adjustments not related to volume, including net profit booking rate adjustments and other matters, were approximately $100 million higher in 2015 compared to 2014, and approximately $105 million lower for 2014 compared to 2013; Operating profit for F-35 production contracts remained comparable, as higher volume was offset by lower risk retirements Additionally, adjustments not related to volume, including net profit booking rate adjustments and other matters, were approximately $105 million lower for 2014 compared to 2013; However, these increases were partially offset by lower net sales of approximately $350 million for the C-130 program due to fewer aircraft deliveries, approximately $200 million due to decreased volume and lower risk retirements on various programs, approximately $195 million for the F-16 program due to fewer deliveries, and approximately $190 million for the F-22 program due to decreased sustainment activities In terms of operating profit, Aeronautics saw an increase of $32 million, or 2%, in 2015 compared to 2014, with an increase of approximately $240 million for F-35 production contracts and approximately $40 million for the C-5 program, although these were offset by lower operating profit for the F-22 program, the C-130 program, and various other programs When comparing 2014 to 2013, Aeronautics’ net sales increased by $797 million, or 6%, primarily due to higher net sales of approximately $790 million for F-35 production contracts, about $55 million for the F-16 program, and approximately $45 million for the F-22 program; //In the Aeronautics business segment, which is engaged in the research, design, development, manufacture, integration, sustainment, support, and upgrade of advanced military aircraft, including combat and air mobility aircraft, unmanned air vehicles, and related technologies, the net sales for the year 2015 amounted to $15,570 million, reflecting an increase from $14,920 million in 2014 and $14,123 million in 2013 The operating profit for Aeronautics in 2015 was $1,681 million, which is an increase from $1,649 million in 2014 and $1,612 million in 2013 The operating margins for Aeronautics in 2015 were 10; This increase was primarily driven by higher operating profit of approximately $85 million for the F-35 development contract, as the absence of the downward revision to the profit booking rate that occurred in 2013 positively impacted results Additionally, there was an increase of about $75 million for the F-22 program due to increased risk retirements, approximately $50 million for the C-130 program due to increased risk retirements and contract mix, and about $25 million for the C-5 program, also benefiting from the absence of downward revisions to the profit booking rate in 2013 However, these increases were partially offset by a decrease of approximately $130 million in operating profit for the F-16 program due to decreased risk retirements, despite increased deliveries, and about $70 million for sustainment activities due to decreased risk retirements and volume

#The overall Total for Pension Benefits is $3,471, and for Other Postretirement Benefits, it is $218 The Company's stock-based compensation plans are described in detail, indicating that shares issued in satisfaction of stock-based compensation may come from authorized but unissued shares, shares held by the Company in treasury, or shares purchased in the open market In the years 2016, 2015, and 2014, the Company issued shares from treasury to satisfy stock-based compensation; All derivatives are recognized on the balance sheet at fair value On the date the derivative contract is entered into, the Company may designate the derivative as a hedge of the fair value of a recognized asset or liability (fair-value hedge) or a hedge of a forecasted transaction or of the variability of cash flows to be received or paid related to a recognized asset or liability (cash-flow hedge) Changes in the fair value of a fair-value hedge, along with the gain or loss on the underlying hedged item, are recorded in current-period earnings; #On the liabilities side, the current liabilities assumed were $310,919, while the long-term liabilities amounted to $494,995, leading to total liabilities assumed of $805,914 Consequently, the net assets acquired in the transaction were valued at $1,042,661 Following the Robert Mondavi acquisition, the Company sold certain acquired vineyard properties and related assets, as well as investments accounted for under the equity method, during the years ended February 28, 2006, and February 28, 2005; The Company realized net proceeds of $170 8 million from the sale of these assets during the year ended February 28, 2006, while amounts realized during the year ended February 28, 2005, were not material It is also noted that no gain or loss has been recognized upon the sale of these assets; This acquisition is collectively referred to as the “Hardy Acquisition ”   Through the Hardy Acquisition, the Company gained one of Australia’s largest wine producers, with interests in wineries and vineyards across most of Australia’s major wine regions, as well as in New Zealand and the United States, along with Hardy’s marketing and sales operations in the United Kingdom In October 2005, Pacific Wine Partners was merged into another subsidiary of the Company; //The current assets acquired in the Robert Mondavi acquisition amounted to $513,782 The property, plant, and equipment acquired were valued at $438,140 Other assets acquired totaled $124,450; Accordingly, the allocation of the purchase price is subject to refinement Estimated fair values at December 22, 2004, are as follows:; In the Hardy Acquisition, which took place on March 27, 2003, the Company acquired control of BRL Hardy Limited, now known as Hardy Wine Company Limited On April 9, 2003, the Company completed its acquisition of all of Hardy’s outstanding capital stock As a result of this acquisition, the Company also acquired the remaining 50% ownership of Pacific Wine Partners LLC, the joint venture established with Hardy in July 2001
