#For resale agreements, the firm typically requires collateral with a fair value approximately equal to the carrying value of the relevant assets Although these agreements involve a legal transfer of ownership, they are accounted for as financing arrangements due to the obligation to repurchase or resell the instruments However, "repos to maturity" are treated as sales, and as of December 2012 or December 2011, the firm had no repos to maturity outstanding; //Securities Lending: The Company participates in securities lending programs whereby blocks of securities, which are included in fixed maturity securities, and short-term investments are loaned to third parties, primarily major brokerage firms and commercial banks Collateral Requirements: The Company generally requires collateral equal to 102% of the current estimated fair value of the loaned securities to be obtained at the inception of a loan, and maintained at a level greater than or equal to 100% for the duration of the loan Market Events in 2008: During the extraordinary market events occurring in the fourth quarter of 2008, the Company, in limited instances, accepted collateral less than 102% at the inception of certain loans, but never less than 100%, of the estimated fair value of such loaned securities; The carrying value of securities loaned was $13,765 in 2012 and $7,182 in 2011 It is important to note that substantially all resale and repurchase agreements are carried at fair value under the fair value option, and additional information about valuation techniques and significant inputs can be found in Note 8 As of December 2012 and December 2011, $38; Interest on these agreements is recognized over the life of the transaction and is included in "Interest income" and "Interest expense " For further details about interest income and interest expense, one should refer to Note 23 The table presents the carrying value of resale and repurchase agreements and securities borrowed and loaned transactions as of December; //The section on Guarantees and Indemnifications states that FIN 45 requires a guarantor, upon issuance of a guarantee, to recognize a liability for the fair value of the obligation it undertakes in issuing the guarantee To measure the fair value of a guarantee liability, we recognize a liability for any premium received or receivable in exchange for the guarantee For a guarantee issued as part of a larger transaction, such as in association with an asset sale or executory contract, we recognize a liability for any premium that we would have received had we issued the guarantee as a single item; #//At December 31, 2018, our contractual obligations for standby letters of credit and guarantees amount to a total of $67,579, with $61,811 expiring in less than 1 year, $2,621 expiring in 1 to 3 years, $18 expiring in 3 to 5 years, and $3,129 expiring after 5 years; The commercial letters of credit amounted to $53 million in 2017, up from $43 million in 2016 The marketing rights were valued at $41 million in 2017, slightly decreasing from $44 million in 2016 The risk participation agreements were $16 million in 2017, down from $19 million in 2016; The Company assesses credit risk associated with letters of credit to determine the necessary reserves for unfunded commitments A liability is recognized on the Consolidated Balance Sheets to reflect the Company’s obligation to be ready to perform under standby letters of credit if specific triggering events occur, with this liability amounting to $3 million as of December 31 for both 2017 and 2016 In 2003, the Company entered into a 25-year agreement to acquire the naming and marketing rights for a baseball stadium in Pennsylvania, having paid $3 million for the years ending December 31, 2017, and 2016, and is committed to pay a total of $41 million for the remainder of the contract; //The summary of outstanding off-balance sheet arrangements as of December 31, 2017, shows that the undrawn commitments to extend credit amount to $62,959 million, while in 2016, they were $60,872 million The financial standby letters of credit totaled $2,036 million in 2017, compared to $1,892 million in 2016 The performance letters of credit were $47 million in 2017, increasing from $40 million in 2016; It is important to note that many of these commitments are expected to expire without being utilized, meaning the contract amounts do not necessarily reflect future cash needs Standby letters of credit, which include both financial and performance types, are issued by the Company to provide conditional guarantees of payment to third parties if customers fail to meet payment obligations or complete specific projects Commercial letters of credit facilitate the import of goods and serve as payment methods for the Company’s customers’ suppliers; The Company’s potential credit loss from counterparty nonperformance is represented by the contractual amounts of these instruments, minus the value of any collateral held Standby letters of credit can be issued for terms of up to ten years, while commercial letters of credit are typically for one year These letters of credit are generally secured by cash, accounts receivable, inventory, or investment securities

#The Company has two reportable operating segments: Risk Solutions and HR Solutions Unallocated income and expenses, when combined with the operating segments and after the elimination of intersegment revenues and expenses, total to the amounts in the Consolidated Financial Statements Reportable operating segments have been determined using a management approach, which is consistent with the basis and manner in which Aon’s chief operating decision maker (CODM) uses financial information for the purposes of allocating resources and assessing performance; HR Solutions partners with organizations to solve their most complex benefits, talent and related financial challenges, and improve business performance by designing, implementing, communicating and administering a wide range of human capital, retirement, investment management, health care, compensation and talent management strategies Aon’s total revenue for the year ended December 31, 2011, was $11,287 million, which includes $6,817 million from Risk Solutions and $4,501 million from HR Solutions, with an intersegment elimination of $31 million For the year ended December 31, 2010, Aon’s total revenue was $8,512 million, with $6,423 million from Risk Solutions and $2,111 million from HR Solutions, and an intersegment elimination of $22 million; The CODM assesses performance based on operating segment operating income and generally accounts for intersegment revenue as if the revenue were from third parties and at what management believes are current market prices The Company does not present net assets by segment as this information is not reviewed by the CODM Risk Solutions acts as an advisor and insurance and reinsurance broker, helping clients manage their risks, via consultation, as well as negotiation and placement of insurance risk with insurance carriers through Aon’s global distribution network

//In assessing the need for a valuation allowance, we estimate future taxable earnings, considering the feasibility of ongoing planning strategies and the realizability of tax benefit carry forwards and past operating results, to determine which deferred tax assets are more likely than not to be realized in the future Changes to tax laws, statutory tax rates, and future taxable earnings can impact valuation allowances related to deferred tax assets The decrease in net deferred tax assets is attributable to the increase in our valuation allowance concerning our deferred tax asset for the Settlement agreement, partially offset by additional accruals under the Settlement agreement and amortization of intangibles; //The valuation allowance primarily relates to net operating loss and tax credit carryforwards for which utilization is uncertain Cumulative tax losses in certain state and foreign jurisdictions during recent years, limited carryforward periods in certain jurisdictions, future reversals of existing taxable temporary differences, and reasonable tax planning strategies were among the factors considered in determining the valuation allowance These loss and credit carryforwards have expiration dates that vary generally over the next 20 years, but no significant amounts expire in any one year; federal and foreign net operating loss carryforwards, or $116 million on a tax-effected basis, $18 million of foreign and federal tax credits and investment allowances, $828 million of state net operating loss carryforwards, or $39 million on a tax-effected basis, and $23 million of state tax credits, or $15 million net of federal tax benefits For the year ended December 31, 2013, the valuation allowance increased by $40 million due to an increase in our valuation allowance concerning the deferred tax asset for the Settlement agreement, partially offset by a reduced valuation allowance related to the use of foreign tax credits and state net operating losses For the year ended December 31, 2012, the valuation allowance decreased by $19 million due to the use of foreign tax credits in connection with the sale of Diversey Japan, offset by an increase concerning foreign net operating losses and our allowance concerning the Settlement agreement; #We place our cash and cash equivalents with high-quality financial institutions, and such balances may be in excess of FDIC insured limits In order to manage the related credit exposure, we continually monitor the credit worthiness of the financial institutions where we have deposits Concentrations of credit risk with respect to trade accounts receivable are limited due to the wide variety of customers and markets in which we provide services, as well as the dispersion of our operations across many geographic areas; #The notes to the financial statements continue with Note O, which discusses derivative instruments and hedging activities Con Edison’s subsidiaries hedge market price fluctuations associated with physical purchases and sales of electricity, natural gas, and steam by using derivative instruments such as futures, forwards, basis swaps, options, transmission congestion contracts, and financial transmission rights contracts Derivatives are recognized on the balance sheet at fair value unless an exception is available under the accounting rules for derivatives and hedging; #For the B-737-800, we have placed orders for 11 aircraft to be delivered in 2009, 21 in 2010, 1 in 2011, none in 2012, and none after 2012, resulting in a total of 33 aircraft, with a note indicating a reduction of 1 aircraft The B-777-200LR has 6 aircraft scheduled for delivery in 2009, 2 in 2010, none in 2011, 2012, or after 2012, totaling 8 aircraft In the A319-100 category, we have no orders for delivery in 2009, 2010, or 2011, none in 2012, but 5 aircraft are scheduled for delivery after 2012, totaling 5 aircraft; The accounting quantity for the 787 program in 2012 is 1,100 units, which is part of our estimate for production under existing and anticipated contracts The undelivered units under firm orders for the 787 program in 2012 are 799 units, indicating the number of airplanes that have been ordered but are yet to be delivered The cumulative firm orders for the 787 program as of 2012 total 848 units, representing the total number of aircraft ordered; For the A320-200, there are no orders for delivery in 2009, 2010, or 2011, with 2 aircraft scheduled for delivery in 2012 and none after 2012, totaling 2 aircraft The CRJ-900 shows that we have ordered 10 aircraft for delivery in 2009, with no orders for 2010, 2011, 2012, or after 2012, totaling 10 aircraft, with a note indicating a reduction of 2 aircraft Overall, the total commitments for aircraft delivery include 32 aircraft in 2009, 23 in 2010, 1 in 2011, 2 in 2012, and 5 after 2012, culminating in a total of 63 aircraft; The accounting quantity for the 767 program in 2012 is 1,103 units, which is part of our estimate for production under existing and anticipated contracts The undelivered units under firm orders for the 767 program in 2012 are 68 units, indicating the number of airplanes that have been ordered but are yet to be delivered The cumulative firm orders for the 767 program as of 2012 total 1,108 units, representing the total number of aircraft ordered; //The accounting quantity for the 737 program in 2012 is 6,600 units, which reflects our estimate of the quantity of airplanes that will be produced for delivery under existing and anticipated contracts The undelivered units under firm orders for the 737 program in 2012 amount to 3,074 units, indicating the number of airplanes that have been ordered but not yet delivered The cumulative firm orders for the 737 program as of 2012 total 7,367 units, representing the cumulative number of commercial jet aircraft deliveries plus undelivered firm orders; The accounting quantity for the 777 program in 2012 is 1,450 units, which reflects our estimate of the quantity of airplanes that will be produced for delivery under existing and anticipated contracts The undelivered units under firm orders for the 777 program in 2012 are 365 units, showing the number of airplanes ordered but not yet delivered The cumulative firm orders for the 777 program as of 2012 total 1,431 units, which includes both delivered and undelivered aircraft

#In the fourth quarter of fiscal 2017, the Company completed its annual impairment testing of intangible assets and identified no impairment; At the end of the year, the balance of goodwill was $93,192 thousand in 2017 and $94,417 thousand in 2016 Goodwill is allocated to each identified reporting unit, which is defined as an operating segment or one level below the operating segment It is important to note that goodwill is not amortized but is evaluated for impairment annually and whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying value may not be recoverable; 8 million, with no Adjustments, leading to a Revised Allocation of $273 8 million During the second quarter ended June 30, 2018, a net adjustment of $5; In the fourth quarter of fiscal 2017, the Company completed its annual impairment testing of goodwill and identified no impairment The Company determined that the fair value of each reporting unit, including goodwill, was in excess of the carrying value of the respective reporting unit In reaching this conclusion, the fair value of each reporting unit was determined based on either a market or an income approach; //In the section titled "Note 4 - Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets," it is stated that the Company had approximately $93 2 million of goodwill at December 30, 2017, and $94 4 million at December 31, 2016; 7 million, with no Adjustments, maintaining a Revised Allocation of $26 7 million For Other net assets, the 12/31/17 Allocation was $23

The Firm does not consolidate the securitization vehicles underlying these transactions as it is not the primary beneficiary, and for a limited number of loan sales, the Firm is obligated to share a portion of the credit risk associated with the sold loans; //The Corporation invests in Asset-Backed Securities (ABS) issued by third-party Variable Interest Entities (VIEs) with which it has no other form of involvement and enters into certain commercial lending arrangements that may also incorporate the use of VIEs, for example to hold collateral These securities and loans are included in Note 4 – Securities or Note 5 – Outstanding Loans and Leases In addition, the Corporation has used VIEs such as trust preferred securities trusts in connection with its funding activities; #Specific reserves in the ALLL for the total TDR portfolio were $587 million and $580 million at December 31, 2012, and December 31, 2011, respectively; TDRs typically arise from loss mitigation activities and may include rate reductions, principal forgiveness, postponement or reduction of scheduled amortization, extensions, and bankruptcy discharges without formal reaffirmation by the borrower These measures aim to minimize economic loss and avoid foreclosure or repossession of collateral In cases where principal is forgiven, the forgiven amount is immediately charged off; //The purchase price as of March 2, 2012, is $3,599 The recognized amounts of identifiable assets acquired and liabilities assumed, at fair value, include cash due from banks amounting to $305 The trading assets, interest-earning deposits with banks, and other short-term investments total $1,493; Some TDRs may not lead to the full collection of principal and interest as restructured, potentially resulting in incremental losses, which have been included in the overall Allowance for Loan and Lease Losses (ALLL) estimate The level of subsequent defaults may be influenced by future economic conditions Once a loan is classified as a TDR, it remains so until it is fully repaid, the collateral is foreclosed, or it is completely charged off; //The total dollar amount of TDRs on accrual status, which are current and have made six or more consecutive payments, was $950 0 million at December 31, 2013, and $981 4 million at December 31, 2012; The total fair value of identifiable net assets is $2,649 Goodwill is recorded at $950, which is an intangible asset accounted for at fair value Troubled Debt Restructurings (TDRs) refer to loans whose terms have been restructured to grant concessions to borrowers facing financial difficulties
#8 billion in 2014, $2 6 billion in 2013, and $2 6 billion in 2012; Our fuel surcharge programs generated freight revenues of $2 6 billion in 2013, $2 6 billion in 2012, and $2; In 2014, the fuel surcharge increased by 6%, driven by a 7% increase in carloadings In 2013, the fuel surcharge was essentially flat compared to 2012, as lower fuel prices offset improved fuel recovery provisions and the lag effect of our programs, which typically trail fluctuations in fuel prices by approximately two months In 2014, other revenue increased from 2013 due to higher revenues at our subsidiaries, primarily those that broker intermodal and automotive services, as well as accessorial revenue driven by increased volume and per diem revenue for container usage, which was previously included in automotive freight revenue; //In the category of Operating Revenues, the Freight revenues for the year 2013 amounted to $20,684 million, which represents a 5% increase compared to the $19,686 million recorded in 2012, and a 6% increase from the $18,508 million in 2011 The Other revenues for 2013 totaled $1,279 million, reflecting a 3% increase from $1,240 million in 2012, and an 18% increase from $1,049 million in 2011 The Total revenues for 2013 reached $21,963 million, which is a 5% increase from the $20,926 million in 2012, and a 7% increase from the $19,557 million in 2011; Other revenues include earnings from our subsidiaries, revenues from commuter rail operations, and accessorial revenues, which are earned when customers retain equipment owned or controlled by us or when we perform additional services such as switching or storage We recognize other revenues as we perform services or meet contractual obligations In 2013, freight revenues from five of our six commodity groups increased compared to 2012, although revenue from agricultural products saw a slight decline; We generate freight revenues by transporting freight or other materials from our six commodity groups, and these revenues vary with volume (carloads) and Average Revenue per Carload (ARC) Changes in price, traffic mix, and fuel surcharges drive the ARC, and we provide some customers with contractual incentives for meeting or exceeding specified cumulative volumes or shipping to and from specific locations, which we record as reductions to freight revenues based on actual or projected future shipments Freight revenues are recognized as shipments move from origin to destination, and we allocate these revenues between reporting periods based on the relative transit time in each reporting period, recognizing expenses as they are incurred
#//In the Engineered Products and Solutions segment, third-party sales increased by 4% in 2014 compared to 2013, primarily due to higher volumes and the acquisition of Firth Rixson The higher volumes were mostly related to the aerospace (commercial) and commercial transportation end markets, somewhat offset by lower volumes in the industrial gas turbine end market In 2015, ATOI for the Engineered Products and Solutions segment increased by $16 compared to 2014, principally as a result of net productivity improvements across most businesses, a positive contribution from inorganic growth, and overall higher volumes in this segment's organic businesses; //In the Transportation and Construction Solutions segment for the year 2015, third-party sales amounted to $1,882, which represents a decrease of 7% compared to the previous year, 2014, where sales were $2,021 This decline was primarily driven by unfavorable foreign currency movements, particularly due to a weaker euro and Brazilian real, as well as lower volume in the building and construction end market, although this was somewhat offset by higher volume in the commercial transportation end market In 2015, the ATOI for the Transportation and Construction Solutions segment was $166, reflecting a decline of $14 from the $180 reported in 2014; However, these positive impacts were partially offset by unfavorable price/product mix, higher costs related to growth projects, and net unfavorable foreign currency movements, primarily due to a weaker euro In 2014, ATOI for this segment climbed by $10 compared to 2013, mainly due to net productivity improvements across all businesses and overall higher volumes, partially offset by higher costs, primarily labor, and unfavorable product mix Looking ahead to 2016, demand in the commercial aerospace end market is expected to remain strong, driven by a significant order backlog; Additionally, third-party sales will include a positive impact from a full year of sales related to the acquisitions of RTI and TITAL, while net productivity improvements are anticipated, although pricing pressure across all markets is expected; This decrease was mainly due to higher costs, net unfavorable foreign currency movements, particularly from a weaker euro and Brazilian real, and an unfavorable price/product mix However, these negative impacts were mostly mitigated by net productivity improvements across all businesses In 2014, third-party sales for the Transportation and Construction Solutions segment increased to $2,021, which was a 4% rise compared to 2013, where sales were $1,951; This increase was largely attributed to higher volume in both the commercial transportation and building and construction end markets, although it was somewhat offset by lower volume in the industrial products market The ATOI for the Transportation and Construction Solutions segment improved to $180 in 2014, which was an increase of $13 from the $167 reported in 2013 This improvement was principally due to net productivity enhancements across all businesses and overall higher volumes, despite being partially offset by an unfavorable product mix and higher costs, primarily related to labor

These conclusions are based on a detailed analysis of the underlying credit and cash flows on each security The gross unrealized losses are primarily attributable to general credit spread widening and foreign currency exchange rate movements At December 31, 2015, the Company does not intend to sell the securities and it is not more likely than not that the Company will be required to sell these securities before the anticipated recovery of its remaining amortized cost basis; At December 31, 2015, the $1,802 million of gross unrealized losses of twelve months or more were concentrated in the energy, consumer non-cyclical, and basic industry sectors of the Company’s corporate securities At December 31, 2014, the $901 million of gross unrealized losses of twelve months or more were concentrated in the energy, consumer non-cyclical, and utility sectors of the Company’s corporate securities In accordance with its policy described in Note 2, the Company concluded that an adjustment to earnings for other-than-temporary impairment (OTTI) for these securities was not warranted at either December 31, 2015 or 2014;
